PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education system, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and the Australian Society generally.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union-controlled Superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice.

(vi) Oppose any backdoor attempts at achieving compulsory unionism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Grimes:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 in a debate that commenced last night. I have pointed out that, while this legislation is important, it is a relatively minor part of trying to ensure that Australian manufacturing industry has a future in Australia. Last night I was emphasising the importance of providing a competitive environment for manufacturing and the failure of the Government to do so. As a result of that failure we are now getting all sorts of concerns being expressed within the Government itself by people such as Dr Theophanous and Mr Bob Brown and, of course, by the trade union movement about the failure of the Government's industrial policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last few days in the Senate we have heard the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) making various admissions as to why there has been a reduction in investment over recent quarters. Senator Button admitted that interest rates were a very significant factor. He referred to uncertainty about the dollar. Yesterday he agreed that wages were an important element in determining the attitude of industry to investment and to future prospects. Now, at the time we are debating these Bills, we have discussions between the Government, industry and the trade union movement on the possible further discounting wages. However, one can only note with dismay the comments made by the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who suggested that, while the trade union movement may be prepared to recognise that there is a need for some further discounting, it is clearly not a discounting that should take place now. There appears to be no intention to interfere with the wage case currently before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I can only express regret for that, given the very doleful view of the economy which has been expressed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

It is also faintly ludicrous that we have a situation in which the Government is now talking to industry about interest rate subsidies for businesses making investments. It seems a very long way away from the Government's stated intentions of producing a more open and competitive economy where there is less reliance on forms of industry assistance than there has been in the past. This Government is now talking to both trade unions and private enterprise about whether taxpayers should be called upon to subsidise the investment in Australian industry which is required if we are to recover our economic capacity and whether taxpayers' money should be devoted to paying part of the interest bill which industry would otherwise have to pay. I can only say that there could be no clearer indication of the failure of the present Government to provide an environment which is appropriate for business than the fact that it has to get into the business of interest rate subsidies. It is only two days since Senator Button admitted in the Senate that the intentional high interest rate policies of this Government were introduced to slow down investment and to slow down economic growth in this country. About half a year after the Budget was brought down the Government is going into precisely the reverse position and talking about subsidising interest on business borrowings. That shows what a high degree of incoherence there is in the Government's present administration of economic policy.

I turn to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1986, which-with the one exception, which I will detail-the Opposition will support. It comprises a number of fairly substantial amendments, including the new developing country preference scheme, changes in assistance for telecommunications equipment and related parts and the removal of duty on grain harvesters and parts following the implementation of bounty payments. That last measure, of course, has the support of the Opposition. The Bill also introduces the Forum Island preference scheme-which is a simplified scheme of reimport concessions-new assistance arrangements for tableware and other goods, a reduction in the wool content requirements for wool carpets from New Zealand and a number of other lesser amendments. Notwithstanding our general support for the Bill, in the Committee stage we will move a request to seek the reversal of the proposed increases in tariffs for optical fibre and optical fibre cables and we will draw the attention of the Government to some anomalies which will result after the implementation of some of the amendments.

I would like the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in his reply to deal with wool carpets. The legislation provides that an agreement made under the closer economic relations agreement will allow a reduction in the wool content in the pile of wool rich New Zealand carpets that are eligible for duty free entry. This is a reciprocal arrangement retrospective to 2 August 1985, the date on which letters were exchanged between the relevant Ministers. Representations have been made by the Carpet Institute of Australia, which has expressed concern about the fact that New Zealand is not making the same statutory changes as are being made by Australia and the Commonwealth and there is some concern about whether the arrangements are truly reciprocal. I would appreciate some reassurance from the Minister as to whether there is any significance in the different way that New Zealand is implementing the arrangement which was entered into between the two countries last year.

I note our support for the removal of duty on grain harvesters and move to the provisions which relate to telecommunications and related equipment. The Industries Assistance Commission examined this industry in 1984 and recommended a phased reduction of the general 30 per cent tariff rate to 20 per cent over two to three years. In this Bill the Government proposes a 20 per cent rate phased in over four years. The Opposition will support this notwithstanding the slower rate of phasing which the Government has introduced. The Government, in accordance with the IAC recommendation, is supporting increases in the tariff applicable to optical fibre and optical fibre cables. The Opposition disagrees with these changes and considers that the tariff rates for these products should not be increased. That decision is one which, on balance, is the argument for making the changes that basically relate to the desire to have uniformity of tariff with other communications equipment and to have some reasonable parity between the tariff imposed on copper cable and that for optical fibre which is the subject of this legislation. The Opposition pays some heed to the principle of neutrality but, as I will indicate a little later, we believe that that very worthwhile principle should not be followed in this case and that we should not be adding an additional tariff in this important new area.

The other argument which might be used to support the Government's proposal for a 20 per cent tariff is that apparently there is something of an oversupply of optical fibre in the world market at the moment. The world market is genuinely very competitive, and that is a further argument which might be used to support the Government's decision. On the other hand, the Opposition has a very substantial concern that we are dealing with an important new item which is going to be very important in the development of communications and related industries in Australia. Effectively, we are dealing with an intermediate good, and the Opposition is reluctant to see what should be very important growth industries in the future saddled with very high cost inputs. Part of our opposition to this is based on the fact that we believe that it is fundamentally important, as Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out in a very important speech he made to the Senate earlier this week, that we should be tackling industry costs wherever we can. To take government action which will increase industry costs is thoroughly counter-productive in the situation in which Australia currently finds itself. We do not want to see potential growth industries put under burdens of the sort which will be imposed by this legislation.

The second reason we are opposing the increase in tariff is that the new industry was established in Australia prior to this tariff decision being taken by the Government. In other words, those people who invested in the industry in Australia did so knowing that there was a fairly benign purchasing policy for Telecom Australia, but without any offer or any guarantee of assistance of the sort which is now being offered by this legislation. So people have been prepared to invest in new plant where there is no tariff protection, and now the Government is saying after the event that tariff protection will be offered. We think that is a very illogical approach to be adopting.

The third reason why we are concerned arises from the representations which were made by the industry itself through the Australian Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association. In the representations which were made to us, in support of the Government's decision, it was pointed out:

There is intense competition for tenders, and prices currently on offer are close to world prices. That is, internal competition will ensure that the tariff will not be fully used in terms of its expected impact on prices.

So even at the point before we actually have the tariff in place, the industry is indicating that it is likely that the tariff will not be fully used because of the highly competitive situation which exists. It seems to me to be quite ludicrous in this highly competitive situation to be imposing new levels of protection which will ease that competitive pressure when, in fact, that competitive pressure is precisely what Australian industry needs if it is to be outwardly looking and internationally competitive in the way Senator Button claims industry must be. In that claim he is supported by the Opposition.

The fourth reason the Opposition is opposing this 20 per cent tariff is that the industry is already obtaining some aid through the assistance which is available to it. That point is well made in the IAC report where it is pointed out that there has been considerable support for research and development. On page 62 of the report it states: Local manufacture of optical fibre and optical fibre cable currently receives substantial government assistance. IR&D grants have been worth an average of about 100 per cent and 30 per cent of optical fibre and optical fibre cable output respectively over the last three years. Since production of both products is very recent in this country, that might be regarded as a temporary phenomenon. Indeed, using projections of output provided by witnesses, the rates of nominal (and effective) assistance for both products drop below 10 per cent within a year or so if the average IR and D grant for the last three years were to continue.

The point is that there has been a substantial level of assistance granted and there will be some continuing assistance through these means. I suppose that the fifth reason we would oppose the 20 per cent tariff is that when there is already a competitive market in Australia it seems a pity to be establishing a tariff which may entice other people to enter into manufacture purely because of the availability of that additional protection. That is not the way we want industry to shape up for what no doubt will be a very difficult and competitive future. In the Committee stage we will move a request for an amendment to that part of the Government's proposals.

The only other matter which I think really needs attention in the legislation is the changes the Government has made to the developing countries preference scheme. Those changes are important not only from the point of view of the immediate impact on trade and Australian industry but also because Australia has been a leader in the field in establishing developing countries preferences. If one studies the report of Dr Helen Hughes, which is the basis for the change the Government is putting forward, one would have to say that, with the wisdom of hindsight, there may have been more effective ways of providing assistance for developing countries. Dr Hughes points out that to some extent this simply encourages distortions in trade rather than the creation of new opportunities for developing countries.

It must be said that the changes the Government proposes, which are in accordance with Dr Hughes's recommendations, impose some order in an area that at present is very confused. The adoption of a general 5 per cent preference is a step in the right direction. It will be more readily understood by our trading partners and by industry within Australia. The fact that the Government has not proposed to admit exceptions is at least a step in the direction of certainty. The Opposition supports the changes that are being made to the developing countries preference scheme. The Government will need to examine very carefully the impact this will have, including the modifications that might need to be made to some of the recommendations of the IAC, where in a number of cases, for example in the recent chemicals report, it suggested that assistance should be provided and that there be no developing country preferences available. I should like some indication from the Minister as to how the Government intends to deal with recommendations of that sort. My assumption is that the Government will stick to its developing countries preference arrangements as established in this legislation and make any necessary adjustments to the assistance provided to particular industries in Australia, taking that into account rather than again getting into the business of making ad hoc changes to the developing countries preference scheme. I do not think any other matter needs to be addressed because in general the matters have been addressed in broader decisions made by the government with respect to particular industries, and they have had the support of the Opposition.

I turn very briefly to the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. This Bill is fairly uncontentious. It makes various amendments to six separate bounty Acts and one subsidy Act. In all these cases, since we have supported the basic arrangements brought down for computers, steel products, ships and so on and since the proposed changes do not alter the intent of the schemes, we will support the legislation. Since the Minister is now in the chamber I wish very quickly to recapitulate a number of points I made before he returned. It is a matter of great concern to the Opposition that after a very lengthy period in which the Government has tried to establish a rational framework for the development of Australian industry very considerable confusion now appears to be emerging in the Government's approach to economic management and to the manufacturing industry in particular.

Senator Button's admission over the last few days that investment in manufacturing is affected by a number of factors-by interest rates, by uncertainty about the Australian dollar and by the situation with respect to wages-reminds us that these fundamentals, which provide the framework for industry, are far more important than the industry specific measures which are before us today. We are now in a situation in which the Government is talking to its trade union partners in the ACTU about the possibility of discounting wages. However, it has been made quite clear that there will be no further discounting in respect of the current wage case. I ask the Minister whether we are in a position where the postponement of action is appropriate, given the very great difficulties we face internationally and, as a result, internally.

I also note with very deep regret the fact that the Government sees itself as having to tackle the problem of investment being impeded by high interest rates by raising the possibility of interest rate subsidies to manufacturers. It seems to me that this is a return to many of the industry practices of the past which the Government had indicated it was trying to get away from. It is tackling the symptom; it is not getting to the cause of the problem. It is a situation in which taxpayers are being called upon to provide a subsidy in the form of a reduction in the interest rate which will have to be payable by business investors. I think this is completely out of tune with the general approach which has been talked about by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce over his three years in office.

We have, in the interests of the redevelopment of the Australian industry, been prepared to give very ready support to those policies of the Government which we think have been in the interests of Australian manufacturers. We now see a situation in which the general environment being provided by the Government is quite incompatible with the general thrust of industry policy. We call upon the Government to make changes to its fundamental approach to economic management which will give some sense of realism to the industry policies which have been pursued by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tariffs which are the subject of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 are very blunt instruments for the protection of Australian industry. I would like to give an example. Tariff protection for Australian produced grain harvesters and combines increases the cost of all imported machines to match the protected price of Australian made machines. In turn, the costs of Australian primary producers are increased by that amount. According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), the estimated cost of this tariff to Australian farmers would be around $8.25m annually. The increased farm costs of grain production results in decreased profit margins for Australian farmers when their produce is exported and sold at ruling world prices. In turn, the decreased capacity of Australian farmers to buy Australian harvesters means that Australian manufacturers of grain harvesting equipment have a net decrease in local sales. So, in the case of grain harvesters, the effect has been exactly the opposite to that which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has been trying to obtain. It is likely that overall tariff protection for this manufacturing industry significantly decreases sales and, commensurately, decreased the profitability of that industry. It also puts the burden of protection for the harvester manufacturing industry on to the shoulders of the farmers. This unjust burden in turn has meant a flow-on need for rural industry support. This has meant that more Government money has flowed outwards and as a result the Government got less revenue from this activity.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible for tariffs to act against the interests for which they were originally put on. As I said, tariffs are, indeed, a blunt instrument. They are a very ineffective tool and result in a very messy business situation because they cannot be directed specifically at an individual industry. It is with some pleasure that I notice that the Government is looking more towards subsidies and bounties and I am very happy with the Bills. For the same reason, I commend the Government's reduction in tariffs on most imported telecommunications products and components. However, tariffs on telecommunications products and components will be reduced only from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. At the same time a new tariff will be introduced to protect Australian manufacturer of optic fibres. We believe in a system of equity. The fledgling industry of fibre optics probably can do with some protection. We would have much preferred a bounty or subsidy system brought in for that industry, which could have been directed in a proper way and not affected those people who use optic fibres as raw materials in their manufacturing process. Tariffs have a first order advantage over subsidies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you tell us whether you have any evidence as to why the fibre optics industry needs protection?

—Senator Sheil has asked why the fibre optics industry needs protection. I will deal with that in detail later in my presentation. We need to develop new types of fibre optic equipment. We also need to handle optical logic equipment within Australia. I believe this would flow on from having a vibrant and competitive industry within Australia which is protected from what is happening in the rest of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Tariffs raise money for the Government. They are a tax on imports of certain goods. On the other hand, bounties and subsidies cost money for the Government and that money must be raised by increasing taxes in other areas. The Government's inconsistent use of tariffs to protect fast growing telecommunications and optic fibres markets is coupled with its change from tariffs to bounties in many other more static markets. This can only be explained by the money that the Government hopes to raise by these measures. I am not certain that that is a good industrial policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This is yet another symptom of the piecemeal, short-sighted and compromising attitude of the Government. I repeat: Tariffs are indeed a blunt tool. In this instance tariffs will fall heavily on imports of components used in manufacture of computers and telecommunications equipment. Yet it is this very industry that the Government hopes to establish in Australia. Companies that manufacture computers in Australia are highly export oriented. They need to be. The government does not buy their computers. Instead of buying locally made computers, the government buys foreign computers through the Department of Defence and other bodies. Australian public servants play safe and buy cheaply from the big boys. We have a colonial cringe mentality in Australia which means that we do not appreciate our own industry. This is really a problem that is not helped by this type of tariff program.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Australian Government to buy Australian products poses extra problems for our computer manufacturers in their export efforts as foreign governments ask immediately how many computers have been installed by our Government. The answer is that the number is quite small. So our manufacturers find it difficult to break into new government markets overseas. Telecom Australia and the Department of Defence have a very bad record for buying foreign equipment in preference to the equivalent local product. Other countries support their industries with preferential buying policies and assume generally that the Australian product must be very bad if our Government does not support an Australian manufacturer by buying his products.

I support affirmative action for Australian industry. Australian public servants must explain their reasons for not buying Australian products, rather than being able to hide behind the `safe option'. They must always, in their buying policies, take into account the eventual cost to Australia from dependence on foreign suppliers and long lines of communication. I ask the Minister what he will do about this `buy Australian' policy.

Almost all components used to manufacture telecommunications and computing equipment in Australia are imported. Extra costs of tariffs on imported components raise the cost of Australian manufacture of computing equipment. This imposes an extra burden on the industry when it comes to compete in export markets and decreases its viability. Bounties are a much more useful tool for protecting Australian industry. I hope that the Government will implement a bounty policy.

Bounties can be given at varying rates depen-ding on particular aspects of an industry which the Government wishes to encourage. This does not distort the rest of the market in any way. For example, bounties can apply to selected components as well as to end products which use those components, thus doubly assisting the industry, rather than the effects tariffs have of penalising end users. We can actually make certain that certain manufacturing standards are followed by putting bounties on products with a certain technological content. Bounties are paid by the whole community and do not unfairly penalise one sector or one group, as do tariffs.

The benefits to Australia of a buoyant export industry must be weighed in the balance with the cost of establishing that industry and supporting it against unfair and subsidised trading practices in other countries. Continuing support for Australian industry, on the other hand, can lead to our industry being uncompetitive, as has been raised by Senator Chaney. We can become lazy about improving our products and manufacturing processes. We can become slack about marketing our products abroad. This has been a problem in Australia for many years. We have looked at our industries as import replacing industries, rather than dynamic export-directed industries. Australian industry spends far too little on research and development to improve our productive capacity. We invest far too little in modernising plant and equipment. We rely far too heavily on local protected markets. We seek added protection when we should be looking to decrease costs and improve our product quality.

I now turn to the fibre optics market which is experiencing a growth rate of between 40 and 60 per cent per annum, reflecting its high growth nature and its association with the telecommunications industry. Fibre optics have advantages over other communications media. They have a higher carrying capacity and cost effectiveness, a better performance than conventional metal cables, radio or microwave transmitters, or even satellites, and are much less vulnerable to interference, much less vulnerable to tapping. They are being used in an increasing range of military and civil applications. Their performance is improving remarkably and their price is falling at a rate of around 25 per cent per annum. Australia's telecommunications laboratories have developed new types of glass fibre made out of new materials like gallium fluoride, which can carry signals in the near infra-red region at almost 100 times the efficiency of conventional silica glass fibres. We need to protect this type of industry. This makes intercontinental optic cables extremely attractive, compared with satellites, as a means of long distance communication between large centres, and there is no chance of their being shot down.

Potential export markets for such optic fibre cables are huge. However, tariffs imposed on components used by Australian manufacturers of optic fibre communication equipment may throw away our current advantage in this market. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce report on optical communications and fibre optics estimates a total Australian market of some $60m by the year 1990 and, hopefully, $300m by the year 1995. TALK.START.PARA: —I deplore the Government's shilly-shallying with tariffs. The overall protection which tariffs give to Australian industry is very marginal. The disincentive caused by tariffs to Australian industry's research and development into new products and new markets is indeed considerable. The final costs of tariffs fall unfairly on Australian manufacturers in industries closely related to those which the tariffs are meant to protect. In short, Australian industry would be far more competitive without tariffs. Bounties can be substituted for tariffs without causing any disruption to the protected industry. We can phase out tariffs and bring in bounties while keeping a stable industrial base. The final cost to Australia of bounties is no more. Bounties are paid fairly by all Australians, who receive the benefits in more exports and more employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I turn to the Bill which deals with bounties, the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, I wish to mention the developing countries' tariff advantage. Currently the advantage is only 5 per cent, except for textiles, clothing, footwear, steel and motor vehicles. Pacific Forum countries will have duty free access to Australian markets, except for the commodities I just mentioned. The sooner we move to a system of bounties for these particular industries the better our relations will be with those countries which produce textiles, clothing and foot- wear. By doing that, we would also, in fact, decrease the overall cost to our own people. We need to cement our economic relations with our neighbours in the Pacific economic community and we need also to use tariff reduction as a support for nations which are less well off than we are.

The Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill batches together amendments to a number of individual bounty and subsidy Acts which subsidise Australian products competing against cheaper imported products of the same kind. The purpose of these subsidies is to provide protection to local production which is considered to be in the national interest, while not penalising other exporting industries through imposing higher costs. Many of these amendments attend to very small details, but one which I consider to be highly significant and wish to concentrate on is the amendment to the Bounty (Computers) Act, which extends the bounty arrangements for computers to include modems and multiplexers. Modems and multiplexers are communication processors which are used to link computers and other devices together, either physically or through telephone, radio or other link networks.

Computer technology is advancing at an enormous rate. In 1970 the largest computers performed 10 million instructions a second; in 1980 they performed 100 million instructions a second; and by 1990 they are expected to perform 1,000 million instructions a second. Costs are also falling. The cost of one logic or gate unit in 1960 was between $1 and $10. By 1990 the price is expected to be 100,000th of the 1960 price, or the equivalent of around half a million units for $1. This increase in performance and decrease in cost has been accompanied by a similar dramatic decrease in size and an increase in performance. Consequent upon this revolution in computer technology there has been and is continuing to be a similar revolution in the use of computers in information processing, automation and control which has had enormous consequences for business, production, defence and society as a whole.

Side by side with the computer revolution has been a revolution in communications technology. Increased band widths, digital data networks, packet switching, satellite technology and optic fibres have all combined to reduce the costs of transmitting information over large distances. Indeed, these trends are likely to continue at the same pace. Australia needs to get on to that band-wagon. The more far-reaching consequences are likely to come from integration of the two technologies of computing and communications. Transmission of computer data, traditional text and voice and images over the same media at the same time to the same user will see another social revolution in the immediate and medium term future. We need to get in on the ground floor of this type of technology. For example, Parliament could sit in each of our home bases in our electorates and we could be linked by multi-media networks. We could perform the work of this Parliament in a much more efficient fashion; we would no longer be subjected to the tyranny of distance.

I believe that we have to buy into this new technology. We need to develop in Australia an industry which is capable of serving our needs into the future. We need an industry that is capable of providing us with the defence and surveillance systems we need. In Australia, where vast distances and a small population until now have been a huge cost, this revolution will bring the whole country together. Support for our computing and communications manufacturing is vital and I congratulate the Government for its action in extending the bounty to include the means of linking computers and other devices into modern communications networks.

Briefly, the other areas dealt with in the Bills, which the Democrats support, are high alloy steel products and stainless steel flat products. It is very important that we should develop a capacity for producing these materials in Australia. We must add more `value-added' to our products. This is why we will be supporting all of the aspects of the Bills.

I commend the Government for bringing in these measures. Through a sensible system of bounties and a reduction of our tariffs we can produce a strong, independent Australia. This can become a reality when we design and build our own naval vessels, which will become possible with the development of our fledgling shipbuilding industry. We can equip our armed forces with communications equipment and computers produced locally so that we will no longer have the problems of very long lines of communication, supply and consequent difficulties of maintenance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Chaney which will have the effect of maintaining at 2 per cent the tariff on imported optical fibres. Standard Telephones and Cables Pty Ltd is building a computer model of the submarine cable system and Amalgamated Wireless Australasia Ltd is investigating the opto-electronic design of undersea repeaters. Australian Optical Fibre Research, which is a subsidiary of Wormald International Ltd, is designing directional couplers. Austral Standard Cables and Olex Cables are working on submarine cable design.

At the moment there are three principal manufacturers of optical fibre cable in Australia-Olex Cables, a subsidiary of Pacific Dunlop, Austral Standard Cables, a subsidiary of Metal Manufacturers, which is supplying Telecom, and Pirelli Cables Australia, a subsidiary of the Pirelli tyre company. The first comprises Pacific Dunlop-the senior partner with a 51 per cent stake-Pirelli and Sumitomo of Japan, which formed Optix Australia Ltd to make fibre, and the company's Melbourne plant was opened at the end of February. This quite clearly indicates that the industry is healthy, growing, expanding, developing, and is doing so without the necessity of a 20 per cent tariff protection and perfectly well within the 2 per cent tariff framework.

Pages 61 and 62 of the Industries Assistance Commission report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts, to which Senator Chaney has already drawn attention, indicate that local manufacturers of optical fibres and optical fibre cable generally have been receiving substantial assistance by way of industry research and development grants which have been worth an average of about 100 per cent and 30 per cent of the optical fibre and optical fibre cable output respectively over the last three years. On pages 10 and 11 of the Australian Science and Technology Council report `Telecommunications Research and Development in Australia', under the heading `Government Assistance to the Telecommunications Equipment Industry', there is a series of recommendations. That the government continue with its proposal to develop an integrated development strategy for the Australian telecommunications equipment industry, in full consultation with industry interests and service providers.

The ASTEC report goes on to make the point that it would be entirely wrong for the Government to undertake steps which would now increase the cost of communications equipment in Australia. The Department of Science recently published a discussion paper entitled `A National Information Policy for Australia'. On page 31, under the heading `Rationale for Government Involvement', there is an indication that it is an important responsibility of the Government to maintain what force it can to keep down the cost of communications equipment in Australia and to encourage the development and transfer in Australia of new technologies. It mentions particularly the significance of the provision of information in our increasingly information-based society. But it seems to me that if we have already a situation of oversupply, a situation involving a fair amount of competition, and provision of these goods at or near world prices, why in the world are we opening up the possibility that there will be a degree of featherbedding in the industry of the sort which the Minister himself has been so ready to criticise in the past? It is also said in the IAC report-I do not think the Minister wants us to read the whole of it, but if he does I will-that there will be some continuing assistance, or it is likely that there will be some continuing assistance, to this industry through industrial research and development grants and those grants have over recent years been very substantial in the assistance that they have provided.

I made it clear in the debate that the Opposition regards the principle on which the IAC recommended assistance-that of having uniformity within a particular manufacturing sector-as a principle that is worthy of serious consideration. It is a matter that was seriously considered by the Opposition. We took the view that, on balance, the other factors I have mentioned are more substantial than the need for uniformity. I thought the Minister was overstating the position with respect to uniformity when he referred to the next paragraph to the one quoted by Senator Puplick which referred to copper cable. It seems to me that we are in a situation where copper and fibre optics are not in complete competition. Obviously there is a degree of competition, but much of the new technology we are talking about would use fibre optics rather than copper for reasons other than price. There are technical reasons, as I understand it, why that would be so. The next paragraph of the IAC report, about which Senator Button was so cross as to its not being referred to, seems to me not to be a complete answer to the point made by me in the second reading debate and subsequently by Senator Puplick.

We happen to be dealing with an area where it has been my publicly stated view that, to the extent we can get sensible common views being advanced within the political process, there is a greater likelihood that we will get sensible conduct on the part of industry. It seems to me that the Minister is now participating with the Government in a series of measures that bear no relationship to the logic that he has been bringing to the argument over the last three years. He is now flapping about talking about interest subsidies for capital investment and various other things which seem to me to be the sort of McEwenism we have heard so much about in the Senate over the last few days. I simply ask the Minister to give us a reasoned and polite response to the issues which we have raised. We have raised the issues which caused us to take the view that, rather than support this particular aspect of the legislation, we should oppose it. If we are wrong, I should like to hear that from the Minister. I have yet to hear anything from him that shows other than petulance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with six Bills-the Dairy Produce Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 2) Bill 1986, the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986, the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986 and the Dairy Legislation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986, which will change dairy industry levies. This legislation is a result of all the discussions and toing and froing that have been going on over the last few months. We would do well to remember that it first started with the infamous and cynical agreement made prior to the Victorian election. This agreement was reached about two days before the election but it was never implemented. Legislation was introduced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), but it did not meet the wishes of the industry and that legislation was severely amended in this chamber. Since then there has been a lot of discussion within the industry to try to get to the stage we are at now.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it must be said that the industry is well aware of the fact that there is overproduction in Australia and it has acknowledged that. I understand that this year overproduction in milk will be of the order of 150 million litres. The industry is State oriented. Whether we like it or not and whether we think it is good or bad, that is a fact of life. Most of the industries have built up within State boundaries. That means that when we are changing some of the structures, looking at market support levies and all the rest of it, some areas in some States are quarantined from what is a major problem. That must be acknowledged. For instance, the State of Western Australia is quarantined. It has an industry which meets its own market. Sections of my State of Queensland are quarantined. The area in which I live-the Port Curtis district-is quarantined, as is north Queensland. The farm which I own with my brother is in the south-east corner. Although that area is not quite quarantined, it has been able not only to meet its market milk requirements but also to mop up the surplus by being very aggressive in the manufacturing and selling of manufactured milk products. It has done this quite successfully. I refer, of course, to the Caboolture co-operative area.

It has to be recognised that there are significant problems in the dairy industry. Some areas are absolved from those problems, yet they are all being asked to come together and, if these Bills are passed, meet the problems that exist. In doing so they will start to make the industry in total more market responsive. Victoria is one area that comes to mind of massive overproduction of the market milk requirements. It has a major problem with mopping up the surplus manufactured milk. Victoria tells the other States that its cost of production is lower and, on the surface, that is quite true. However, one has to acknowledge the fact that a lot of the Victorian produce is seasonal milk. Of course, anyone who milks seasonally can keep down his costs of production as against someone who tries to meet the market requirements 12 months round-in good seasons and in bad, in wet and in dry weather. As one tries to meet the requirements in the drier part of the year, one obviously has to feed grain, molasses or whatever other supplements are available and so one's costs of production rise.

Where we are at today is, I suppose, a compromise. Politics, amongst other things, is the art of compromise and we have reached a compromise with this legislation. I quote a letter from Mr Pat Rowley, President of the Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation. He states:

It is not correct to say that the Australian Dairy Industry Conference/Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation . . . endorse this legislation but on the other hand we accept it is probably the best compromise that can be reached, given the divisions within the industry itself and overall Government policy.

I think that sums it up pretty well. I suppose it is usual for honourable senators who are debating something in which they have an interest to declare that interest. I am probably the one person in the whole Parliament who, as a result of this legislation, will be forking out more money. It will cost me money. I will be a recipient of very little money because my market is not very export orientated.

This legislation will make the industry more market responsive. It will see government regulations reduced, and that is to be welcomed. It will also see the levies standardised on a milk fat basis. I am paid cents per litre for market milk on a quota basis, but for manufactured milk payment is in cents per kilogram of butterfat. It is a good move to standardise the levies on a milk fat basis, but I think we have to look beyond the present and recognise that, particularly with a lot of low fat products coming on to the market. If we want to be market sensitive, we have to look to levies which go beyond the milk fat content and look to levies on protein or solids, not fat. We have products such as casein and cheese which have a high protein content. A lot of the products coming on to the market, such as the yoghurts, creams, custards, and flavoured milks, are based on low fat milk. So we have to look beyond a levy on the butterfat content alone and look to the protein content, or the solids, not the fat. That will help producers when deciding on their herds and how their breeding will operate. As I said, the payment for manufactured milk, is in cents per kilogram of butterfat. The industry requires a minimum of 3.3 per cent butterfat, but if one is to be levied on fat, one will not have a herd which produces a very high content of fat in the milk. It will be up to the producer to keep his production within the levels required by the industry and by the market.

Various levies, of course, are structured for the Australian Dairy Corporation itself-for promotion, research and market supply. It should also be said that clause 6 of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill 1986 was the last sticking point in the negotiations. It is the escape clause or what has come to be known as the comfort clause. In order to offset the anxiety in some States about supporting exports of dairy produce via a levy on all milk in the event of the collapse of the market milk prices, the Government has agreed to insert this escape or comfort clause. The inclusion of this clause in the legislation is endorsed by all State dairy farmer organisations. As I said, that was the last sticking point in the negotiations, and the Minister for Primary Industry agreed to put that in, and we thank him for that.

There is another point which is of concern for the cheese manufacturers. There are pretty strict requirements on the standard of cheese made in Australia. It is of a very high standard. As I understand it, little or no colouring is allowed, and very little, if any, preservative is allowed. That is all right; we can live with that. However, we have imported cheeses. People, as in many other instances, rave over the imports and say they are better than the home-grown products. These cheeses are not subject to the same health requirements. They should be. The question of who will be responsible for the testing and the implementation of the health requirements which are in existence for our own cheeses is placed in the too hard basket. I say in passing that it is hard enough for our own manufacturers to compete with imports, but when they find that imported cheeses are not subject to the requirements which our own producers have to meet, that is beyond the pale.

In conclusion, I pay tribute to Mr Pat Rowley, who is the President of the Queensland Dairymen's Organisation, for his role as President of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. It has been a long hard battle for Pat. He has spent very little time attending to his own business. Over a period I saw him at airports almost as many times as I saw my parliamentary colleagues. He certainly has had a tremendous amount of work to do. He would almost reach agreement a few times and it would fall to pieces. Ultimately, he has been able to weld the industry together, diverse as it is, with all the differing problems State by State, and achieve general agreement on these six Bills which are before the Senate. Some areas and some States will not be happy, and for very good reason. They are paying into a levy scheme which will not advantage them one little bit, except that in the long run it will make the total industry more market responsive. It will help if we bring our overproduction down to a level which means that we can meet our whole milk requirements within this nation and still service the good markets which we have built up overseas. Victoria, for example, has an export market of whole milk powder. I believe Tasmania has built up some good markets overseas. If we can bring our overproduction into line with the requirements of those overseas markets and the domestic market, this legislation will be worthwhile, and those people who are quarantined will accept the fact that they are paying for something which is of no benefit to them in the short term but which will ultimately benefit the total industry. The Opposition will be supporting these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I ought to declare my interest in this legislation. I am not in any way connected with the dairy industry or even the farming community. In my time in this country, particularly when I was intimately involved in the trade union movement, it could have been said that I was on the opposite side to the rural community. There were a number of reasons for that. We are debating the Dairy Produce Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 2) Bill 1986, the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986, the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986 and the Dairying Legislation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: I am doing something now which I did not think was possible two, three, or even five years ago, and that is standing and speaking in the defence of rural Australia-the farmers, the graziers and the pastoralists. In my time with the trade union movement, it could have been said that I was at the opposite end of the spectrum to them. I got a distorted picture of what the rural community was about, and that distortion arose not only from my ignorance of the industry, even though my ancestors came from farming stock back in Ireland, but also from the rural community itself-the farmers, the graziers and the pastoralists, with the dairy farmers included. When one read the papers, listened to the radio or watched television, one always seemed to be hit with a constant scream from the rural community that it was a bad year. The hand always seemed to be out for more assistance.

In my early years in Australia I saw a horrific incident in Perth when the then Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, was subjected to a barrage of abuse and even violence from the farming community in Western Australia. We saw the Western Australian Government defeated in the 1974 election because of the withdrawal of the superphosphate bounty. That was one of the main reasons for its defeat. My viewpoint became distorted because at the same time as we heard the pleading screams for help and assistance we had reports of record prices for wheat, record shipments of wheat, record prices for beef, burgeoning new markets for live sheep and so forth.

I could never understand the contradiction which seemed to occur in these matters-on one hand we heard cries for assistance and on the other hand we were told that primary industry was doing very well. Imports of cars, particularly Mercedes Benz, have increased. Many imported high-cost items were being brought in by farmers some of whom were doing very well indeed. My change of opinion did not arise because of the demonstrations we were subjected to in recent months in Canberra and in other places throughout Australia or because of the actions organised in the main by the National Farmers Federation-the blockade, the sit-ins. Even the actions of farmers in King's Hall sitting down and playing Monopoly did not bring about my change of opinion.

Because I am a representative of Western Australia-I see myself as a representative of all the people, rural as well as urban dwellers- I felt the need to be more informed about the rural crisis. I would have liked an invitation to attend the meetings held outside this Parliament but no invitation was forthcoming. At one stage I even considered gate-crashing the meetings but the awful crying-in-the-beer music, the country music, that was being played really turned me off. So I did not attend. Because of my history with the union movement I could understand the reactions of those people-the mass movement that we witnessed here in the last few months. I could understand their anger and frustration because certainly something was wrong along the line. The anger and frustration of the farmers perhaps was misdirected. It ought to have gone down different channels. The events of last weekend when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went rural and talked in a reasonable and rational manner with the rural community show that we can get action not necessarily by taking to the streets. We have learned that in the trade union movement over the years. Now the National Farmers Federation and others are also learning that lesson. It is a very good lesson to have to learn because some of the actions in which we engage bring with them a number of dangers.

One of the greatest dangers of such actions is that of dividing the nation. As a nation we are divided enough among the States. I represent a State. But we do not want to divide the rural community from city folk. If there is a crisis-and I believe there is-in rural industry it will not be solved by turning one against the other and dividing us. We have to face the crisis collectively. Some of the actions of the National Farmers Federation involved some danger that that might happen. Hopefully the National Farmers Federation is learning; I commend it for its organisation of demonstrations. It is good that people organise, stand up to bureaucracies and governments and express their points of view. But safeguards have to be built in. That is happening at the moment in the rural industry.

I am a wee bit fearful of the latest reports that the NFF has organised another fighting fund, this time of $10m. It is interesting that the National Farmers Federation throughout Australia has pinpointed nine seats which it will target in the next Federal election. I wonder whether it really intends to spend $1m in each of those seats and have $1m around for the rest of its propaganda. That is a legitimate activity for any organisation to engage in. We are also looking at targeting some seats in Western Australia for the next election. We might be working in close concert with our country cousins-our colleagues in the National Party-on that matter.

What brought about my greatest appreciation of the conflict in the rural sector was that in April this year I joined the Prime Minister's country task force. It is headed by the honour- able member for McMillan, Barry Cunningham, and includes two Western Australian representatives, the honourable member for Brand, Wendy Fatin, a member of the Caucus agriculture and primary industry committee, and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Graeme Campbell. We spent three days in Western Australia and met a very large number of people in groups and as individuals over a meal. We did not waste too much time. We met the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia representatives, the Primary Industry Association of Western Australia representatives, members of the Country Women's Association, individual farmers and farmers of the future when we had dinner at the Muresk Agricultural College at Northam in Western Australia. We did not confine our discussions and the people we met to those in Labor-held seats. That was done with some difficulty because the Labor Party holds the majority of seats in Western Australia. We had to search around a little to find a seat that we did not hold. There are only three and one of those is a metropolitan seat.

One of the very interesting things I learned on that trip-it is a reflection on me as I did not know it before-is that the Australian Labor Party holds more country seats than does any other political party. That is an achievement for the Labor Party which is seen to be anti-rural and anti-farmer. It is also a reflection on those parties which have purported to represent country interests in the past. It is also a reflection on the good sense of the rural people who elect representatives such as Wendy Fatin to the seat of Brand in Western Australia and Allen Blanchard to the seat of Moore. The people are getting good value for money in those seats. We ventured into Cunderdin in the Federal seat of O'Connor and had valuable discussions with rural people. We obtained a real appreciation of the difficulties faced by people on the land.

There is no doubt that there are problems, grave problems, for individual farmers. Some farmers are also doing quite nicely indeed. Even in areas such as Southern Cross, which is on the edge of the desert, we were told that more money is being held in banks than is being loaned. The problems of the farming community arise from a number of factors with international trade being perhaps the most important and the most serious. The protectionist policies of the United States and the policies of the European Economic Community give us problems. It is said that dairy farmers in the European Economic Community overproduce by 2 or 3 per cent. To get that into some form of perspective, that 2 or 3 per cent of overproduction represents the total production of dairy produce in Australia and New Zealand. High interest rates received a good mention during the tour by the rural task force. It ought to be said that whilst the rural community and farmers are suffering bankers are doing quite nicely by charging high interest rates. They are forcing people on the land to make the hard decisions of getting out or walking off. In some cases land is sold under them. We have had many reports of that in recent months and years.

I turn specifically to the Bills. There is no doubt that the dairy industry is in trouble. It could even be said to be in chaos, particularly in Victoria. What the Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, has done is bite the bullet. He has forced hard decisions to be made in the interests of the nation. However, some of the decisions that have been made in the national interest are going to cost farmers in some States money and they may not necessarily see this as acting in the national interest. It is unfortunate that we have a political structure within which the six States are competing against each other rather than acting as one unitary government when we could make decisions. John Kerin has done a commendable job in pulling the six States together and getting some measure of agreement on the legislation before us today.

The legislation is going to hurt farmers in my State, and it is for that reason that I am speaking in this debate today. The Western Australian Government has made many representations to have changes and alterations made to the legislation because of the impact it will have on Western Australia. Whilst it could be said that the industry was in chaos in a State such as Victoria, that was not the case in Western Australia. The hard decisions that were required were made in Western Australia some 10 years ago and the industry has continued to be fine-tuned since then. The Western Australian Minister for Agriculture was told that the cost of the plan to Western Australian farmers would average out at about $171. The Western Australian Department of Agriculture has done its own estimates and, in its opinion, the figure of $171 is not a true estimate of the cost to Western Australian dairy farmers. The Department of Primary Industry in Canberra estimates that $171 to be the average loss to Western Australian farmers from farm cash operating surplus as a result of the proposed Federal dairy plan.

Julian Grill, the Western Australian Minister for Agriculture, argues that the estimates of the Federal Department of Primary Industry are incorrect and are based on incorrect presumptions. He has outlined a number of shortcomings in those estimates. One is that they are based on Bureau of Agricultural Economics survey results which may not be indicative of either the actual situation or the distribution of any impact across Western Australian dairy farmers. He also argues that the figures wrongly assume production of an equal proportion of market milk and manufactured milk in Western Australia. He quotes the fact that manufactured milk represents 36 per cent of Western Australian milk production. Further, he argues that the calculation ignores 16 per cent of the milk production covered by the Western Australian special products milk quota system, which already attracts domestic market premiums and, in general, will not benefit from the proposed Federal plan. It is said that the figures also assume that the benefits, direct and indirect, from export support mechanisms will flow back to dairy farmers in the absence of administrative rigours to achieve this. Further, it is argued that there will be strong sellers with no price discounting in the Australian domestic market in the absence of pooling of export returns. We should remember that Western Australia is not an exporter of dairy products.

I have asked for the plan to be recalculated. It is estimated that the cost to dairy farmers in Western Australia will be something like $2,350 on average across dairy farms. I have made representations to the Minister for Primary Industry to check the accuracy of the Western Australian Government's arguments. However, at this stage I have not received a reply. Perhaps this is partly my fault because I have not pursued this matter with the vigour I ought to have-I was expecting this debate to be brought on next week rather than today.

The Western Australian Government's position can be summed up by quoting a telex which was sent by Julian Grill, the Minister for Agriculture, to Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industry. Mr Grill argues that there are no sound economic reasons for Western Australia to participate in the plan. He points out that if for constitutional reasons Western Australia has to be part of the Federal plan, Western Australia would ask that some conditions be satisfied. Those conditions are set out in the telex as follows:

(A) That a special mechanism is established whereby an equivalent amount to the total levy collected in Western Australia is returned to Western Australian farmers. This mechanism would recognise that:

Western Australia has, through a three-tier pricing system and industry restructuring, controlled its milk production so that the industry is now geared to supply only sufficient milk and cream to meet the demand for fresh milk and short life products throughout the year. (This requires a minimum of surplus milk to be produced in the spring).

Any significant reduction in the production of milk in Western Australia could jeopardise the continued availability of fresh milk and short life products to consumers throughout Western Australia at all times.
Western Australia is a net importer of manufactured dairy products mainly from other Australian States.
Western Australia is isolated from the rest of Australia and is not contributing to the national dairy marketing problems.
(B) That all milk and cream (including UHT) entering Western Australia for sale would appropriately reflect retail prices for such products in the State of origin.
That is to compensate for any dumping.

In conclusion, I think the rural community is in some degree of crisis. I do not think that this Government in Canberra should be compounding that crisis for Western Australian dairy farmers, who had the foresight to sit down some years ago, take the hard decisions, rationalise and come up with a profitable and businesslike industry that has served Western Australia well. I commend these Bills to the House and I welcome the support they are receiving from all parties. Hopefully, some arrangements can be made to ensure that Western Australian dairy farmers are not adversely affected by this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost a year ago we debated a comparable package of dairy legislation. After some extensive debate in this chamber, three of four major amendments were made to the legislation. However, the Government then shelved the legislation because it refused to accept the amendments made by the Senate. That legislation was introduced in an attempt to rationalise the industry. In fact, the dairy industry is one of the industries in Australia which in the past have undergone major rationalisation. I think it is extraordinary that this industry should again find itself in dire difficulties, almost 10 years after the massive upheavals which resulted in many dairy farmers going bankrupt.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the major problem facing the industry is the differential production operations in each State. Legislation governing the operation of the dairy industry differs from State to State. Up until recent times, there has been little control of the industry in some States, notably Victoria. This has led to a massive expansion of the industry, not so much in terms of numbers but in terms of production. There is, of course, the constitutional complication that it is possible to sell from any one State into another State. Under the Constitution, producers cannot be stopped from engaging in that operation.

It is for that reason that in the last few years every State based industry saw itself threatened with a dairy war in which only dairy farmers would suffer. Of course, in the short term the consumer would have benefited but in the long term the consumer would have suffered. In the short term the dairy farmers would have suffered massively. For that reason the Australian Dairy Industry Conference was mindful of the need to come to some type of national arrangement. It is a national arrangement that not everybody can be happy with but that everybody can live with. The Kerin plan was accepted in part by various industries. Probably the strongest support came from the Victorians, although ultimately they also rejected it in the form in which it was presented. There was agreement that the Kerin plan as modified by the Senate would have been acceptable. However, it was not acceptable to the Government at that stage.

The next move in this saga was when the Australian Dairy Industry Conference put another plan to each of its State affiliates. That was for a two-tiered price structure. The fourth amendment that I moved last year, almost to the day, would have allowed a two-tiered price structure plan to operate. I still believe that the two-tier price structure plan put by Mr Rowley and the Australian Dairy Industry Conference, accepted by the Government but ultimately again rejected by the Victorian dairy farmers, would have been the best plan for all of the operations in Australia, and in the long term would have had a far better chance of success than the one with which we are now dealing. But, unfortunately, we had nowhere to go on that. Without the co-operation and support of the Victorian industry, which is of course dominant in the dairy industry in Australia, there was no chance of success.

We then had a subsidiary movement in the retail field which added urgency to the matter. That was the coming together of the retail chains. The reason that this added urgency was that it was fairly obvious that the retail giants could have entered into arrangements with producers in one State to sell their products in all States at a level, initially at least, way below the price for fresh milk delivered at the door. This would have destabilised the normal operations of the State industries, would have led to the demise of house deliveries in those States which have them and would then have led to a situation almost identical to that which happened with bread operations some years ago. It would also have meant a significant destruction of various industries around Australia at the expense, ultimately, of the consumer. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference saw this very clearly. Unfortunately, some of the people running the various State industries did not see it quite so clearly. With the destruction of the two-tiered price structure plan, they pushed on with a further attempt to come to some type of general agreement. I must admit that at that stage I had given up all hope of getting agreement amongst the various State based industries. I fully expected that we would be launched into a destructive milk war.

However, we now have before us a package of Bills which at best I suppose have an uneasy acceptance around Australia. If this type of operation is not enthusiastically welcomed, at least there is a willingness to give it a try. Even at that low base I am particularly concerned that all State based industries try as hard as possible to make this operation work. If they do not, we will see a massive operation with dairy farmers disappearing from many of the places in which they currently operate at a reasonably profitable level. I had discussions on these Bills with a particular group of dairy farmers and pointed out to them that the actions that they wanted to take would have destroyed dairy farmers' profitability in other parts of Australia. They said that they could not care less, which is an attitude that I find totally reprehensible. But that type of attitude is all too prevalent in this country.

I welcome these Bills. I welcome the grudging acceptance of them by the various State based industries. I congratulate the Australian Dairy Industry Conference for its blood, sweat and tears over the last year in getting this back into the Senate in a form acceptable to all parties. The first amendment moved last year dealt with export pooling. The Senate sought an extension of export pooling for two years. The industry agreed to accept the Government's position on this issue on the condition that an alternative mechanism be introduced, which was export licensing and which appears in these Bills. There we see the willingness of the industry to adapt to the reality of the circumstances. The second amendment was to phase out product levies. The Government proposed what I described as an absolutely crazy formula that would not have given the type of necessary market signals. The current operation makes much more sense. In fact the mechanism in these Bills is not so different from the one proposed in the amendment moved by the Opposition last year and supported by the Australian Democrats.

The third amendment which related to the method of determination of export support payments is somewhat more complicated. Perhaps the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will respond at the close of the second reading debate as to what the Government proposes with regard to clause 98 sub-clause (2) of the Dairy Produce Bill in terms of the trend price. As I understood it, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics was to look at some type of seven-year averaging operation to determine the trend price and then to look at an 85 per cent support mechanism with regard to that trend price as an underwriting. I would be interested to know whether the Government has details of this because the Bill simply says that this will be prescribed. The change in the level of support from 30 per cent of the three-year average of export prices to 30 per cent of the current price makes the whole milk powder problem, that we were discussing last year, far less significant. Indeed, hopefully, this mechanism will work now that the industry has accepted the position in this legislation.

As I have already said, the substance of the amendment of the Democrats for a two-tiered price option, which was not accepted by the Government or the Opposition parties, was what the ADIC put to the various State bodies and which the Victorian industry refused to agree with. What we now face is a somewhat uneasy future in this area. The industries have held out for two propositions, both of which the Government has accepted. The major one, of course, is consultation with the industry. I believe that that consultation is an absolutely necessary part of making these Bills work. I think that the industry has shown its willingness to engage in constructive discussions with the Government. I hope that the various State based industries will continue their support for a unified approach to the Federal Government on this matter so that the industry can, over time, adjust the amount of production, bring it back into line with our domestic market, and then look at the export operation as being an area that is supported by the entire industry in Australia, even though not all sectors of the industry actually are involved in the export operation.

I hope also that the industry, in looking at the way in which this plan works, gives attention again to the two-tier price structure which means that, on the one hand, there is a guaranteed percentage of the domestic market and, on the other, there is a free operation of the export market; that is, members of the industry get what they can on the export market. I believe that the aggressive operations in the export market are currently showing some success. There seems to be some prospect of the upgrading of a number of our manufactured milk products. We need to search aggressively around the world for markets for milk products so that we might be able to use the excess that we currently have, rather than winding down that part of the industry. Eventually, we should be able to build up this export area. The European Community in the last year has cut back on its overall production to try to bring its internal surplus under some type of reasonable control. The European Community has chosen to use the two-tier price structure. I believe that ultimately the various industries around the world could co-operate on that basis. I think we could then have a sensible international export market and a stable domestic milk market in each of the producer countries.

I wish this legislation well. I cannot say that I am overly hopeful that it will actually work. But I believe that, given the goodwill that has been demonstrated by the very hard bargaining that has gone on in the last years, I am positive that within the next year of two the industry will certainly abide by its commitments and the Government will abide by its commitments. We will then have at least a couple of years in which to try to stabilise the industry so that, hopefully, we will have a prosperous industry for the people who are involved in it, without the continuing upheavals we have seen in the last 10 years.
