DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CITIZENSHIP AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Senate that the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill be debated cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a mere truism that any change to the Australian Citizenship Act immediately arouses interest in the Parliament and in the community generally. The community is vitally concerned about changes in citizenship which deal with the character, identity and political and legal status of all Australians. In the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill the Government brings a range of proposals before the Parliament without consultation with the wider community, migrants or the Opposition parties. As with the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, which is subject to debate in the Parliament-we are not sure whether the Government intends to proceed with that Bill-the Government wrongly believes that it has been given a mandate to change the character of Australian citizenship. The Government will, it seems, make these changes by pushing through this Bill regardless of community or public opinion. The Opposition rejects those jackboot techniques. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) reflects a new trilogy; a lack of consistency, a lack of clarity in this legislation and, most important of all, a lack of consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Government propose in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill? Firstly, it seeks to address the claims of residency based on children born in Australia. Secondly, it seeks to change the situation of Australians in Israel who have lost their citizenship. Thirdly, it seeks to change the oath and affirmation of allegiance. Finally, it seeks to make numerous other changes in relation to administrative matters. The Bill seeks to remove automatic citizenship for children born in Australia of visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens. It will thus close the loopholes which have allowed infants to sponsor their own parents. The Government also considers the situation of stateless individuals in this legislation. The Bill will allow appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where citizenship is denied or not granted by reason of some administrative oversight or error. The Bill proposes a number of technical amendments relating to the replacement of sexist language and the waiver of fees. The legislation, as we read it, appears to meet most of those aims.

The Opposition supports these proposals, with the exception of the amendment in clause 7. Clause 7 of the Bill relates to people who have inadvertently lost their citizenship, and the Opposition will be moving amendments in respect of that clause. We hope that we will have the support of the Australian Democrats on that matter. Turning to the matter of the oath or affirmation, we oppose the changes outright.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—I will tell Senator Colston why in a moment. The Government's proposed amendment relating to non-automatic granting of Australian citizenship to children born in Australia will close the back-door entry of people, particularly prohibited non-citizens, who would not normally meet the requirements for Australian immigration. Investigations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure have resulted in a recommendation for an alteration to this aspect of the citizenship law, which has been in effect since 1948. The Committee confirmed that parents who were illegal immigrants would acquire residential status and resist deportation on grounds that the child who had gained automatic Australian citizenship needed the parents' constant attention. This is just another instance of those with no real claim on Australia receiving considerable benefit ahead of those seeking immigrant entry through the proper channels. The Expenditure Committee revealed that up to 25 per cent of illegal immigrants receive health care, social welfare, unemployment benefit and legal aid, the cost of which could amount to over $25m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Human Rights Commission has expressed concern about automatic child citizenship and concluded that better supervision by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would remove or substantially reduce those problems. The Human Rights Commission seemed to have more compassion for illegal immigrants than commitment to the best interest of Australia. The Human Rights Commission has used the issue to propagate its own vested interests. It is the stalking horse of the proposed Bill of Rights.

Clause 7 of the Bill is the area of most concern. It arises from the amendment to the Australian Citizenship Act in 1984 which gave the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs the power to restore Australian citizenship which was lost inadvertently. Those amendments caused some Australians actually to lose their citizenship. Up to 2,000 citizens living in Israel as permanent residents at that date lost their Australian citizenship. Under Israeli law, every person of Jewish descent is automatically conferred with Israeli citizenship on arrival as a permanent resident, unless those people realise that they need to reject the offer of citizenship within three months. The principal intention of Australians going to reside in Israel is not to acquire Israeli citizenship, or to deny their Australian citizenship. The people concerned either had no knowledge of, or had received poor advice on, the implications of the law on their return.

The Bill allows former citizens to make a statement to the Minister and there is a consequential ministerial discretion to reinstate that citizenship. While in general terms we believe that that is a good thing, the Government's proposals are not entirely satisfactory. For instance, the Opposition does not believe that permanent residency within three years is required. That was an unconscious action which deprived Australians of their nationality, and their distress and sense of alienation have been completely justified. All that is necessary, surely, is a statement of their intention ultimately to reside within Australia. The Bill contains an inconsistency. The statement to be furnished to the Minister is based upon the person having suffered significant hardship or detriment. On the other hand, the Minister's discretion is exercised on the basis that the person suffered hardship or detriment of an economic nature. We will be moving amendments to clarify that clause.

Turning to the matter of the oath or affirmation of allegiance, the oath which is administered to people at the time of accepting Australian citizenship is being significantly changed by this Bill. The main change is that no person now, if this Bill passes, will be required to renounce his or her allegiance to the sovereign of any other state, nor will a person be required to state his or her name when taking the oath or affirmation. The Minister in the House of Representatives has said that the renunciation of allegiance is ambiguous and unnecessary. The Minister contends that some candidates for citizenship think that they are renouncing not merely formal ties with their former country but also their cultural heritage and tradition. On that point the Minister is most confused and certainly incorrect. Renunciation of a former allegiance surely is a positive step in recognition of the legal requirement and the individualism and status of the Australian identity. Allegiance is acquired through birthright. Naturalisation brings with it a feeling and a declaration of identity. We believe there is a clear principle here. While any person should retain his or her private, personal, cultural and individual character, there is a higher and stronger national character, a public identity, in which the allegiance to one's chosen country is absolutely paramount. Such an allegiance implies both the benefits and the responsibilities of national duty.

Australia is not alone in requiring a renunciation. A number of countries that have a similar background and status also require renunciation. I instance Italy, Malta, Yugoslavia, West Germany, the United States of America and Cyprus. Even the Soviet Union requires renunciation in the oath, on the application for citizenship or in its law. In one form or another, that renunciation is required.

Back in 1982 a report was commissioned by the former Minister for Immigration, Mr Macphee, entitled `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship'. In that report it was stated that there was less unanimity in the proposals compared with other proposals about what should be substituted as the object of allegiance. The report noted that the discussion on renunciation tended to lack clarity and that views were wide-ranging. Some suggested that a renunciation was not legally binding while on the other hand the report stated that it was thought highly repugnant that a person granted Australian citizenship should retain allegiance to any other country or power. The general conclusion was that it is probable that clearer wording would resolve some of the apparent disagreement. The report declared that Australian citizenship should be clearly Australian in character. The Minister has chosen, unfortunately, to reject that conclusion in that earlier report. Instead, the Government has chosen to follow the proposal of the Human Rights Commission. I would have thought that the process of bipartisanship would have been followed, but there has been no consultation with the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia on this matter. I am sure that, over a period, an acceptable form of words for the oath, based on the suggestions in that report, could have been achieved. But that is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you referred to consultation with community groups.

—No, consultation with both the community and the Opposition, which represents a very sizable part of the community. Even in some countries which allow dual nationality, such as Switzerland, the applicant is required to refrain from any act which may acknowledge former citizenship, and renunciation is demanded. If the Minister is using this amendment to send out a signal that Australia is moving towards dual citizenship, it is a poor and inappropriate method by which the Government is commencing that discussion. Such important changes should, and certainly do, command consultation with all interested groups. As far as it is known to the Opposition, there has been no consultation on any of those matters, other than those consultations that were held in 1982 under the regime of the then Minister, Mr Macphee. Those consultations, as I mentioned earlier, were inconclusive and wide-ranging and suggested changes to retain renunciation as part of the oath. Obviously, the Minister has not consulted widely, nor has he opened debate on the question of wider public scrutiny or the accountability that he has to the public at large.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition clearly understands the continuing private bonds that some of our citizens feel for their country of origin. Even though traditions and external pressures on our citizens may be significant to those people, as a nation we cannot diminish our national identity by accommodating a wide variety of individual and sometimes conflicting obligations. The Opposition believes that a renunciation of other allegiance in the oath does not deny a person's private cultural heritage. However, it is an important step towards recognising one's Australian identity. The age of a resident and the length of residency are major factors in the decision to become as Australian citizen. Personal, social and financial investments made by people over a period influence the probability or the lack of probability of a return to their former country.

In 1983 the `Australian Values Study' found that 86 per cent of the population was proud of its country. Regardless of any country of origin, commitment to Australia is alive and well amongst our people. The study found that the two largest migrant groups were even more committed to Australia than the average Australian, those two groups being southern Europeans and the British. It does seem to the Opposition that the Minister wants to devalue the allegiance.

This Bill also refers to the deletion of one's name when a person takes the oath. Surely this merely decreases the personal value of his or her pledge at the time of taking the oath. The oath cannot be applied to anyone else but the individual who makes that commitment. Although the Minister dismisses this requirement as confusing, surely that is not the case. It depends on the competence of the local officers conducting the citizenship ceremony and the practices and traditions of all local authorities which undertake those ceremonies. A solemn oath or pledge demands a legal and personal identification with the commitment being undertaken. Indeterminate commitments lack compulsion and complete acceptance of the serious contract that follows.

The Opposition is opposed to the removal of an individual's name when he or she is making the pledge or affirmation or taking the oath. We reject any depersonalisation of that process. We do not believe that any attempt at making it less significant for a new citizen to realise his or her rights, privileges and responsibilities as an Australian can be tolerated. As I mentioned earlier, during the Committee stage of the debate we will move amendments to clause 7 to cover that point.

I turn to the Migration Amendment Bill 1986, which is being dealt with cognately. This Bill is to be amended as a direct consequence of provisions in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. The Migration Amendment Bill relates to clause 4 of the Australian Citizenship Bill. This Bill makes changes to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill to provide for the Government to define more carefully exactly who is an Australian citizen. Clause 4 of the amending Bill changes section 10 of the principal Act. These changes, which have been passed by the House of Representatives, remove the right of automatic citizenship for children born in Australia whose parents are prohibited non-citizens, temporary entrants or visitors. There is an obligation to determine what status under migration laws should be given to these children. If they cannot be citizens, what should they be? Infants are dependent upon their parents, especially upon their mothers, and if their parents are prohibited non-citizens, temporary entrants or visitors, what should be the status of those children in the Australian community? Before the changes, these children would have been Australian citizens because of the fact that they were actually born in this country.

The amendments to the Migration Act confer the immigration status of parents on their children. If the status varies between parents, the status more favourable to the child will be given-that is, the longer time left to remain in Australia. If the parents' status is equal, the child takes the status of both. During debate in the House of Representatives the Opposition gave its support to the proposed change to the Australian Citizenship Act. It accepted that an amendment to the Migration Act was necessary to carry through the intent of the citizenship changes. However, it must be understood that changes to citizenship law are significant and very important. We need more debate in this area in the community generally.

The fundamental right of citizenship has previously been based on the common law principle of jus soli-that is, the attribution of nationality on the basis of place of birth, irrespective of parentage or race. The principle of jus soli contrasts with another principle, that of jus sanguinis, where a person's citizenship is determined by the citizenship of the parents-a principle that has not been previously applied in Australia. From now on, for children born of prohibited non-citizens, temporary entrants and visitors, citizenship will be based on blood ties-that is, citizenship as determined by the citizenship of the parents. Also, children who would otherwise become stateless will be protected and will acquire Australian citizenship. The legal principle of citizenship by place of birth is not entirely abandoned by these changes but it is severely restricted. The tradition of citizenship is incorporated in the laws of the United States of America, Canada, Argentina, Brazil, New Zealand and Fiji. The United Kingdom, which gave Australia its common law tradition, recently revoked the right of jus soli for children of illegal immigrants. The procedure, as it stood, was open to exploitation by those seeking to achieve residency.

Factors that we believe need to be considered from a national point of view cover the following points: First, the traditional principle developed in the United Kingdom and Europe that people move from one country to another for reason of permanent settlement; secondly, fast and easy international travel today does not denote a degree of permanency in any one country; thirdly, in recognition of that fact, the United Kingdom has recently removed the birthright citizenship and few countries in the world now confer automatic citizenship on birth. The main reason for changing the citizenship law was that problems arose when prohibited non-citizens abused the citizenship law in order to obtain permanent residency in Australia, based on the citizenship of their children. We believe that we should adopt an alternative approach, based on the principle that there is a traditional right of citizenship dependent upon birth. The Government appears to be taking the opposite view. It is denying citizenship to children so that it can take action against parents who may be illegal immigrants. Surely this has very little to recommend it. Australia is one of the few remaining countries that accept large scale immigration. Obviously immigrants are of great value to this country because we need citizens. The Government's objective in removing abuse of citizenship could have been achieved by restricting citizenship and changing the Migration Act to prevent any claim by parents or children to permanent residency.

The Opposition has decided that the complete removal of traditional rights cannot be supported. It accepts that the Government's approach of denial of citizenship solves one particular problem. However, we will move an amendment to the relevant clause. This amendment will allow compensation for the removal of automatic citizenship rights. That will be done by permitting those people born in Australia of non-citizens or non-residents to take up permanent residency between the ages of 18 and 40 years. Where such a person applies for citizenship between those two ages, that person would be subject only to minimal character, security and health checks. He or she would not be required to meet all the normal immigration criteria. There is provision for these people to become Australian citizens in due course.

We think that that is a sound decision which will allow an element of retention of the recognition of one's place of birth and prevent the abuse of our national rights at the same time. At the age of 18 persons born in Australia of non-citizens or non-residents will have the right to return to the place of their birth and join the Australian community. Conditions would be light and certainly not obstructive. Under our amendment a young adult would be given a chance to make a decision, almost an automatic decision, to join the Australian community. The amendment includes an upper limit of 40 years. Whilst that is arbitrary, it allows that person to migrate with his family when generally he would be in a stable position and could still make a substantial contribution to Australia before reaching retiring age. The Opposition is confident that it has found a more reasonable and sensible answer to the problems than the Government's. The messy approach that the Government has adopted has been taken apparently without consultation and in a desire to ram through this legislation at the close of a very long sitting.

Merely changing the citizenship law and the Migration Act will not stop the tide of illegal immigrants. That requires concerted administrative action with clear directives from the Government. Those who should be given incentives to come to Australia are being neglected; those who should not come seem to be encouraged by the present regime. The Opposition has strong views on a program that is balanced between economically sound migrants and those who come as a result of family reunions. We all know that there are so many heartbreaking cases. The Opposition wants to see an increase in immigration, supported by domestic policies of smaller government and employment training opportunities, particularly for young people. The purpose of the Opposition amendment is to give an opportunity to children who have been born in Australia to adopt Australia as their permanent home. We call on the Australian Democrats to join with us on this matter and successfully amend this legislation. If accepted, the amendment will not only achieve the Government's objective but also achieve it with far greater equity than was intended in the Government's legislative approach. As I mentioned earlier, at the later stages of these two Bills we will move amendments to relevant clauses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Government in its proposals in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1986. Try as we might, we cannot find any equity or even common sense in the proposals put forward by the Opposition to amend these Bills. In fact, we regard some of the proposed Opposition amendments as positively silly. We also wish to commend the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) for the progressive look he has taken at the problems posed by the current legislation and we warmly support his proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills represent a rationalisation of the laws relating to the acquisition, loss renunciation, deprivation and resumption of Australian citizenship. The most significant amendment means that automatic Australian citizenship will no longer be conferred on children born in Australia. That is a significant move in this field and it is one which the Democrats support. The conferring of citizenship by birth under the present Australian Citizenship Act has been mercilessly exploited by illegal immigrants and visitors who have deliberately had a child in Australia so that those children may become permanent residents and the parents can therefore become automatic citizens of this country. This loophole in our law-and this is what it is-allows contemptible queue jumping to the detriment of not only those who are waiting all over the world to be processed for entry into Australia but also the hundreds of thousands of people living in Australia who are desperately seeking to bring their loved ones to this country. Some have argued: What difference does it make-I think this is the Liberal argument-if several thousand extra people per annum stay in Australia using the back door, jumping the queue method?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not the point at all.

—That is what the Liberals are saying. The Democrats say that there are about one million people in the world who want to come to Australia. Nine out of ten who apply properly will be rejected because we can accept only 100,000 people per annum. The several thousand who abuse the system take the places of those who want to come here and who apply under our immigration laws. If we want to take more migrants-an idea the Democrats are not opposed to-we should increase the intake but we should not allow people to stay who are here illegally and who contrive and conspire to have a child for the simple purpose of allowing them to jump the queue. We will not have a bar of that.
—But our amendment will not bring that about.

—It will bring exactly that about. This Bill now before the Senate has raised the question in some quarters as to whether there is a fundamental or natural right for a child to acquire the nationality of the country in which it is born. As I understand it, that is the argument put by Senator Messner. One can easily have sympathy with that argument. It has logic and some morality on its side. The question is an important one and one about which we have thought long and hard. It is our belief that it is a general rule of international law that it is up to `municipal' law to determine who is and who is not a subject of any state or country. Article I of the International Convention Relating to the Conflict of Nationality Laws ratified by Australia in 1937 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: It is for each State to determine under its own law who are its nationals. This law shall be recognised by other States insofar as it is consistent with international conventions, international customs and the principles of law generally recognized with regard to nationality.

None of the other major international conventions are phrased in terms of the fundamental right to acquire nationality by birth. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1948 does not mention the right to nationality by birth. The American Declaration of Rights and Duties of Man 1948 does not mention it, nor does the American Convention of Human Rights. Proposed new section 23d of the Australian Citizenship Act does comply with Australia's international obligations on nationality. While the right to nationality by birth is a fiction, every child has the right not be be stateless. I think we have to make the distinction between the two. Article 24 (3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states that every child has the right to acquire nationality. It does not state that this nationality must be that of the country in which a child is born. In 1973 Australia ratified the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. The amending Bill before the Senate today is in line with this Convention.

The effect of proposed new section 23d-clause 8 of this Bill-will be that stateless children would acquire Australian nationality by birth. I refer to my use of the term `stateless children'. I use the phrase reluctantly. I do not use the term `illegitimate children', as that is an unnecessary and unjust reflection on the child instead of reflecting on the parents, who are in fact illegitimate. Essentially a stateless child is either a child of stateless parents or a child of parents who, for some reason or another, cannot or should not return to their country of origin. Under this legislation, no child will be allowed to be stateless. The Australian Government has been forced to act by people exploiting the system. The Human Rights Commission has recommended that the law be changed and hopefully the string of claims from parents that they cannot be deported because their children are Australian citizens because they were born here and therefore they cannot be deported will cease.

The other Bill being debated cognately with the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, the Migration Amendment Bill, simply amends the Migration Act to bring it in line with the new provisions of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. The second purpose of this Bill is to amend the oath and affirmation of allegiance to remove the requirement that in order to become an Australian citizen one has to renounce all other allegiances. I fully concur with what the Minister said in his second reading speech and disagree with the Liberal Party's view. The Minister said that the renunciation is ambiguous and unnecessary and that some candidates actually believe that they are renouncing not only their former nationality but also their cultural background and all other ties with their country of origin. Countless people whom I have had the pleasure of joining at the naturalisation ceremonies have recounted that belief to me. The Government is to be commended for its sensitivity on this issue. It has consulted at length with the State governments and multicultural groups as well as the Human Rights Commission. It has considered the possible alternatives and come up with a simple oath or affirmation.

I accept Senator Messner's criticism. If the Minister did not consult with the Liberal Party he was remiss. I accept Senator Messner's word that the Minister did not. That is certainly a point of criticism of the Minister. This matter should be as bipartisan as possible. The renunciation of all other allegiances is essentially symbolic. As far as I can discover, it has no legal meaning whatsoever. This is not a party political issue because, as I understand it, Senator Crichton-Browne has questioned in this chamber the need for renunciations, as have Senator Harradine and I. From now on those people who will be Australian citizens will say at ceremonies that they will be faithful and loyal to Her Majesty, that they will observe the laws of Australia and fulfil their duties as Australian citizens. I ask Senator Messner what else he wants. Surely to goodness that is enough. They will swear loyalty to Her Majesty, swear that they will observe the laws of Australia and swear that they will fulfil their duties as Australian citizens. Do we want to penalise them for becoming Australian citizens by putting them through the extra agony of saying to them `You will have to renounce all former allegiances', which is quite confusing and ambiguous for a candidate seeking naturalisation?

The third aspect of this Bill is that it will allow the resumption of Australian citizenship for persons who lost their citizenship under section 17 of the Act, as amended in 1984, if they have a continuing commitment to Australia. It appears that thousands of Australian citizens lost their Australian citizenship when they acquired the citizenship of another country. Some lost it because they were unaware of the consequences of taking another nationality; others lost citizenship because they were given incorrect information from officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; still others, under the laws of foreign countries, were compelled to lose their Australian citizenship.

One large group of people caught in the citizenship anomalies were members of the Australian Jewish community, many of whom, having lived in Australia for decades, returned from Israel to discover that they were no longer Australian citizens. The Minister has the power under existing legislation to reinstate Australian citizenship under certain circumstances. The Minister has already agreed to exercise his discretion in these cases. The Democrats agree with the Minister, but for some extraordinary reason the Liberal Party proposes to move an amendment to this proposal. The main group affected is the Jewish community. I have a letter from Mr Mark Leibler, President of the Zionist Federation of Australia, which clearly indicates that those who are affected-namely, the Jewish citizens who lost their citizenship-are completely satisfied with the Minister's stated intention to exercise his discretion and reinstate Australian citizenship to those who lost it through no fault of their own but because incorrect information was given to them by officers of the Department. Apart from this group of people, the Minister has indicated that he will broadly exercise and interpret his discretion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter and a Press release from Mr Leibler. I apologise for not having got Senator Messner's authority for this but he was talking at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Australian citizenship will be restored to those who have been in Australia for not less than two years and have an intention to return to Australia within three years. That is, those who have a continuing contact with Australia or those who lost their Australian nationality through no fault of their own-that is to say, they did not intend to lose it-will have it restored. This is a perfectly reasonable attempt by the Government to ensure that justice is done and is also seen to be done. The last aspect covered by this Bill is a schedule which removes sex specific language from the Act and for this the Government is also to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, in the debate when this Bill was first introduced, the Opposition moved an amendment to alter the clauses dealing with the reinstatement of Australian citizenship. The Opposition spokesperson, in moving the amendment, claimed that he was doing so on behalf of members of the Australian Jewish community. I do not, and cannot, accept that this is the case. The letter and the Press release I have incorporated in Hansard clearly indicate that the Bill as it stands, together with the Minister's undertaking to exercise his discretion in these cases, meets with the complete and total approval of those people affected. For that reason it is beyond my comprehension why the Liberal Party of Australia persists in moving this amendment to a clause in the Bill which is designed specifically to help members of the Australian Jewish community when the Australian Jewish community says that it is satisfied with the Bill and the Minister's undertakings. We commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill fulfils four main intentions of the Government. Firstly, it will exclude children born in Australia to visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens from automatically acquiring Australian citizenship by birth. Secondly, it will amend the oath and affirmation of allegiance to remove the requirement to announce one's name and the requirement to renounce all other allegiances. Thirdly, it will allow resumption of citizenship to persons who lost it under section 17 at any time, subject to a continuing commitment to Australia. Fourthly, it will effect other minor and formal amendments to the Act, such as removing sexist language and anomalies and to make the legislation more specific. We are also debating the Migration Amendment Bill which makes consequential changes to the Migration Act. I will be concentrating on the first two issues I mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be general agreement on the first point about no longer conferring automatic citizenship by birth. As previous speakers have mentioned, a number of prohibited non-citizens, commonly called illegal migrants, have sought residence on the basis of having had a child born while they were in Australia illegally. I guess that the main purpose of this change in the law is to get around that situation, as was recommended by the Human Rights Commission, which has had to deal with some of these very difficult cases. It has been said that people have contrived to obtain Australian residence by virtue of having a child here. I suppose that there are really three categories of people involved. There are those who deliberately have a child while illegally in Australia in order to argue that, because they have had a child who is an Australian citizen by birth, they ought to have the right to remain with it. I suppose that that is contriving a situation where a new-born baby sponsors its parents for permanent entry to Australia. The second category is where a pregnancy occurs in Australia and the parents think that that might be an excuse to argue for remaining in Australia themselves. The occurrence was not necessarily deliberately contrived in the first place but they seek to obtain Australian residence because of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that still happen these days?

—I think it does in some cases. Thirdly, there is the category of temporary visitors who are temporarily visiting Australia who do not intend that a birth should occur in Australia but because of prematurity it accidentally occurs. We argue, and I think it is now generally agreed, that in none of those cases ought a child automatically obtain Australian citizenship. Only a few countries allow automatic citizenship on the basis of birth. Apart from Australia, which is soon to be changed by this Bill, those countries are New Zealand, the United States of America, Argentina, Fiji, Brazil and Canada. I understand that those are the only countries that retain this rule. Of course, in countries such as Britain and many other European countries birth does not automatically result in citizenship. I wish to quote from a letter written by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, on 27 May in response to the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists, which has been writing to the Minister saying that it disagrees with the removal of what it has described, wrongly, as a fundamental human right. Mr Hurford pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that, when neither of a child's parents is an Australian citizen or permanent resident, the Australian community should have the opportunity to select who should become one of its citizens. To argue to the contrary means that anyone can select his or her child's citizenship irrespective of whether the community agrees. The Government cannot accept this and is obliged to protect the community's interest.
Mr Hurford also pointed out:
The Government takes the view that citizenship should not derive from the location at birth but through the child's parents. If one were to accept your proposition-
that is, the proposition of the International Commission of Jurists--

that place of birth is the determinant factor one would be forced to accept that birth overseas to Australian citizen parents should not entitle the child to Australian citizenship. Such a proposition is contrary to the existing provisions of the Australian Citizenship Act which automatically confers citizenship upon the registration of children born overseas to Australian citizen parents.
The right which is being curtailed is not a fundamental human right but a legal right conferred by the Australian Citizenship Act.
Mr Hurford goes on to point out, as has already been said:
This right is being abused today by persons who seek to use the birth of a child and its Australian citizenship as a reason for remaining here.

If people think about it they will realise that the argument is perfectly reasonable. That is, if an Australian tourist happens to have a child born in another country, whether we are talking about North America, South America, Africa, Europe or whatever, that child automatically obtains citizenship of that country and not Australian citizenship. I think most of us would object to that. We are trying to bring Australian law into line with that in respect of children born in Australia. It needs to be pointed out that we are not talking about a child who has grown up in Australia seeking Australian citizenship; we are talking about new-born babies whom we cannot argue have acquired any cultural link with Australia. Because of the recognition that the child has grown up in Australia and perhaps ought to have Australian citizenship, it will be allowed if a child has been in Australia for 10 years. In that situation the child can obtain Australian citizenship, but in the case of a newborn baby, definitely not. I do not think there is any argument for it. The other exception that will be allowed is to ensure that a child born in Australia who would otherwise be stateless-I notice Senator Chipp objected to the use of that term-can then be granted Australian citizenship. We are ensuring that we do not add to the problems of that child by insisting that it remain stateless. We have an obligation to provide some citizenship to such a child.

The other aspect of the Act that is being changed-the Opposition is opposing this change outright-is in relation to the oath or affirmation of allegiance at a citizenship ceremony. I hope that we can continue to use the term `citizenship ceremony' rather than the old term `naturalisation ceremony' which unfortunately still falls from some people's lips. It is an outdated term which we ought to make sure is removed from our language. It implies that a person was somehow or other not natural before expressing allegiance to Australia. The main reason why the Opposition is opposing this change in the law is its jingoism. The Government believes that if new citizens who have been resident in Australia for some time and who have taken what I think is a big step to decide to become Australian citizens, affirm their allegiance to Australia, it is unnecessary to renounce former allegiances. The one implies the other. Many new citizens are confused by the renunciation clause and think that it refers to cultural, religious or other such heritage.

I have attended many citizenship ceremonies. A number of times I have actually distinctly seen people's lips not moving for that particular phrase. I can understand their taking that attitude. People are bothered about it. I think it is time that we removed it because people have their heritage and the strong term `renounce' should not be used. In the case of new citizens from other Commonwealth countries, it is ambiguous. They are asked to renounce their allegiance to the Queen so that they can affirm their allegiance to the Queen. The renunciation that presently exists assumes that new citizens do not really understand what they are doing by becoming Australians when in fact because of the thought that they have, in most cases, given to this, they probably have a better understanding of their rights and obligations as citizens. Most citizens who are Australian by birth do not make this conscious decision. I thought I understood Senator Messner to say that we must have this renunciation clause because it brings a feeling of identity. I would have thought that a negative term such as `renunciation' does not bring a feeling of identity at all; the positive claim of allegiance brings identity. If we are talking about cultural identity that is not and ought not to be changed by asking people to renounce allegiance.

The other aspect of the change in the statement of allegiance is that we are no longer going to require people to state their name in the middle of this oath or affirmation. I think that is a sensible move, again, from my observation of citizenship ceremonies over the years. When a group of people are trying to say the same words in unison, it makes it very difficult if that is interrupted so that they can say their own name, which can take a different length of time. It ends up being very messy because they are not in unison and some of them decide not to continue to speak at all and it reduces the effectiveness of the ceremony. The situation is that people are called up to the front by name; they have a certificate in their name and they know what they are saying when they state: `I swear' or `I affirm allegiance to Australia and agree to obey Australian law'.

The Opposition seems to want big, showy citizenship ceremonies. It wants to put people under its thumb and say: `You renounce your former allegiance and have allegiance only to Australia'. I think we ought to encourage much more the attitude of people being citizens of the world rather than having merely sole allegiance to one country. To force them to renounce everything in their past is an insult and is unnecessary. It is not required under any international law.

I make the point that we can argue that the granting of Australian citizenship is a great privilege. We ought to also acknowledge that Australia is privileged that so many people from all parts of the world, from many different cultures, apply for Australian citizenship. When I speak at citizenship ceremonies I try to avoid saying `Congratulations' to the new citizens because in some ways I see that as a bit paternalistic. I try to remember to say: `Thank you for joining us. It is you, as new citizens, who are honouring Australia rather than Australia doing you a good turn'.

The Opposition has foreshadowed an amendment to the Migration Amendment Bill which is being debated with the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill with the intention, apparently, of confusing the fairly simple change in the Citizenship Bill limiting Australian citizenship by birth. It seems that the Opposition wants to create a new category of person. Instead of having the simple situation on the one hand of an Australian citizen and, on the other hand, those who are not citizens, it wants to have another category of what might be called `potential Australian citizens'; that is, to allow people who were born here accidentally by being born to a tourist or deliberately to an illegal non-citizen to be defined as potential Australian citizens or contingent non-citizens. These people are non-citizens until they actually ask to come back at some later point in their life. The Opposition is suggesting that once they turn 18, even if they were here for only a week after their birth, they should have some right of entry into Australia. The confusion that the Opposition wants to introduce ought to be rejected. I am pleased to hear that this is the Australian Democrats' intention.

Senator Messner suggested that the purpose behind the amendment was somehow to compensate those who would now be denied citizenship by birth. The Opposition is suggesting that such people should be entitled to return to Australia some 18 to 40 years later and be subjected to minimal procedures about their health or character. It really does confuse the simple change that is proposed to be made to the Citizenship Bill. The Opposition is claiming some supposedly traditional right that it did not acknowledge at the time of the debate when the Citizenship Bill was first dealt with in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press report to which Senator Ray refers.
