It is too late to get Menzies, McEwen or Lynch, but Fraser and Howard are still around. Mr Valder's duplicity in saying that he was looking forward to the Labor Government introducing all the tax reforms that the country needed and then, so he thought, a subsequent Liberal government reaping the benefits of those tax reforms would, I suppose, make him a perfect witness for such a tribunal.

ANSWER.PARA: In Mr Valder's favour, I remember that in 1979, I think, as President of the Sydney Stock Exchange, he issued a Press statement indicating that he had refused applications for renewing or regranting dealers licences from some defrocked former Patrick Partners members. It is a pity that Mr Valder as President of the Liberal Party could not enforce the same standards as he did in the Sydney Stock Exchange.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Government seriously considering, under pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Unions of course, offering interest rate subsidies to business and industry in an attempt to encourage investment? If so, does the Minister agree that this represents for him, and for the Government as a whole, a significant change in the direction of industry policy?

—The Government has been considering a number of matters in relation to the trade balance and that issue has certainly been considered. However, no decision has been made about it or any other matter related to it at this time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does not the fact that the matter has been considered, even if that consideration has not been finalised, and the fact that the Government is thinking along that line represent a soft option for the Government? Does it not really mean that the Government has given up hope of taking other, admittedly more difficult, action to bring down interest rates which would produce durable results?

—It is not a soft option; the honourable senator's original question was about a soft loan. That is a matter which, as I said before, has been considered. In respect of any of these matters, it depends on whether they are of universal application or not. For example, in answering the second part of the honourable senator's question, the investment allowance which was provided by the previous Government and the depreciation allowance which was suggested by the previous Government are similar types of schemes. The research and development allowance is a similar type of scheme. Whether those things are necessarily in conflict with economic rationality is a matter for judgment in respect of which universality or otherwise is an important issue.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation recognise that, while it is welcome that most seats in aeroplanes are in non-smoking zones, there is a continuing health and comfort problem for non-smokers in airport terminals? In respect of those areas of airport terminals which the Minister for Aviation controls and which Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd control, such as departure lounges and ticketing, baggage and seat allocation queues, will he ask the Minister for Aviation to undertake to ensure that non-smoking areas are introduced in lounges and waiting areas and that smoking is banned in queues so that those who choose not to smoke can avoid the offensive and health threatening pollution from those who choose to smoke in public areas?

—In response to Senator Coates's question regarding smoking and non-smoking areas, he will probably recall that the Minister for Aviation gave the airlines the option of extending non-smoking facilities on aircraft several months ago and did not receive a very positive response. The airlines said that the non-smoking areas currently zoned on aircraft were meeting the current need. The Minister's view on the question of protecting the interests of the non-smokers is well on the public record. However, Senator Coates has asked whether the Minister will be prepared to set aside specific areas, I presume zoned areas, in the lounges which come within the jurisdiction of the Minister for Aviation for the purpose of protecting the health of non-smokers. That is a very interesting development which obviously would receive the consideration of the Minister so that the interests of both the smokers and the non-smokers could be protected. As far as I am aware, it is free for all at the moment in smoking lounges. No special areas are set aside for the growing non-smoking component of the population. Therefore, there would be some validity in having such steps taken by the Government through the Minister. I will certainly refer the request to the Minister for his consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I refer my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it follows the remarks that he just made to Senator Messner with regard to the introduction of schemes which would assist private investment, such as the investment allowance and research and development schemes, as well as other things which were mentioned by him. I noted the remarks he made in that connection and I was interested that the investment allowance was mentioned because, amid all the speculation of the last few days, I do not think it had been mentioned. Are the investment allowance and the other schemes which were mentioned by the Leader of the Government in the Senate part of the submission which has been made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions with regard to encouraging investment, which I noted the Leader of the ACTU has stressed is vital to the recovery of employment prospects and the economy generally? If the investment allowance is not within the recommendations of the ACTU, what items were regarded as important by the ACTU to encourage investment?

—I do not recall whether there was a reference to an investment allowance in the document which the Australian Council of Trade Unions gave to the Government. There were some 20 items which were very varied. I am not yet in a position to have made an assessment of the relative merit of the number of items but they are on a very wide scale of assessment in terms of merit. I do not have the document in front of me and I have not studied it in detail but I believe several items were directed towards investment matters-but not a universal investment allowance as such, as I recall.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the home insurance scheme administered by the Defence Service Homes Corporation. Is the Minister aware of large premium increases being quoted by a number of private insurance companies as a result of recent flood and cyclone damage and the increased costs of building materials? Is the Minister able to outline any policy changes that may have been initiated by the defence service homes insurance scheme to help contain ever-rising costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be aware that the Defence Service Homes Corporation runs its own insurance scheme, which is available for veterans who are buying their home or those who have been able subsequently to pay off their homes. These arrangements are very satisfactory from the point of view of the participants. As a result of very good management by the Corporation it will not increase its premiums this year for those covered by its operation. That represents not only good management but also the restraint which has been suggested by the Government in all matters affecting price.

ANSWER.PARA: The premiums which are paid to this publicly owned instrumentality on houses in the various States show a very marked concession against those offered in the private sector. For example, in Senator Colston's State of Queensland, for a weather-board home whose cost approximates $60,000 the current premium, which will be the same in the next financial year, is $43.50. However, if a person insured with Suncorp Insurance, one of the big insurers, the cost would be $171 which, the honourable senator will appreciate, is a very big difference. It would appear from the figures that have been provided by the Corporation that in every State it is about $100 cheaper, in round figures, to insure with the publicly owned insurance Corporation than it is to use the services offered by the private insurers, or even the State government insurance offices. There is no doubt that the home insurance scheme run by the Defence Service Homes Corporation is very profitable and efficient and can provide services at considerably reduced costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the rather confused answer that he gave to a question by Senator Messner. Is the Minister saying that the Government is considering granting selective concessions on interest rates rather than a general concession? If so, does the Minister agree that this represents both for him and for the Government a significant change in the direction of industry policy? I ask further: Is that not a confession on the part of the Government of failure to be able to do anything about interest rates generally, which the Minister a couple of days ago told us were the first cause of the drop in investment in this country?

—It is not a confession of failure. Throughout the history of this country, and indeed in many countries, both general and selective instruments of industry policy support are made available by governments. I think in almost every country other than Australia which has a large manufacturing base, selective measures of support are made available to industry sectors through the taxation system. I have already answered that the Government is considering a wide range of measures, amongst which the provision of soft loans is one. No decision has been made.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to the article in today's Australian Financial Review reporting on Caspar Weinberger's comments in relation to Australian participation in the strategic defence initiative? Does the Government consider it appropriate for an alliance to encourage Australian industry to participate in such activities in view of the Government's express wishes?

—I have seen the remarks attributed to Mr Weinberger in the article to which Senator McIntosh refers. The Government's position remains as set out by the Minister for Defence on 8 April. The Australian Government does not endorse the SDI concept and, as a result, will not be entering into negotiations of any sort to establish an umbrella agreement of this kind for SDI research. This will preclude Australian participation in research funded under the SDI program. The United States Government is aware of the Australian Government's position, both on SDI as a whole and on Mr Weinberger's invitation to enter negotiations on an umbrella agreement. Cabinet will consider how best to handle any remaining areas of uncertainty which may arise, but that consideration will strictly conform to the basic policies outlined by the Minister for Defence on that occasion.

—My question, which I direct to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the announcement a month ago of agreement on the basic elements of the assistance package for the heavy engineering industry. Given that the program is due to start operating in about three weeks time, when will the Government be announcing details of the labour and capital adjustment aspects? Is the Minister having difficulty persuading Cabinet about the level of interest rate assistance?
—The answer to the first part of the question is, very soon. The answer to the second part of the question, as to whether I am having difficulties, is no.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an article in yesterday morning's Age by Claude Forell titled: `PM starts to pay for tax cowardice'? If so, is the article accurate in terms of the Government's tax strategy? Perhaps the Minister will explain to the Senate and to Mr Forell the Government's tax strategy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the article to which Senator Elstob refers. It begins with this sentence:

ANSWER.PARA: The public outcry against the fringe benefits tax is a timely reminder to the Hawke Government of the high cost of political cowardice.

The article goes on to say that the Government made a huge mistake in not accepting a broad based consumption tax of the kind put forward last year in the C option. That is a judgment. Leaving aside whether that should have become policy or not, I want to make the point that Mr Forell, like many other journalists, seems to have completely forgotten that the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the ending of deductibility for entertainment expenses and the Australia Card, which are all now controversial and which were in option A presented to the National Taxation Summit, were also in option C. Leaving aside any value judgment or economic judgment, just as a question of fact, anybody who is saying that the controversy over the ending of a series of rorts and ramps and rip-offs which have been practised for a long time by the people whom the Liberal and National parties represent, would not have happened if last year the Government had adopted and enacted as policy option C is simply wrong. It just is not so because all those things and more were in the option C package. I am disappointed that a journalist of Mr Forell's calibre has so quickly forgotten just what was in option C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that State and Federal governments will have to accept cuts in their expenditure plans if the country is to get out of the economic crisis it is now in? Does the Minister accept the claim made by the Victorian Treasurer that the Victorian Government has been more successful in restraining expenditure than has the Federal Labor Government? If so, will this success be reflected in the financial treatment Victoria receives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I could off the top of my head give a valid assessment of whether the Victorian Government has been more successful than the Commonwealth Government in restraining expenditure. Indeed, I do not know the time period to which Mr Jolly referred. In 1983-I refer to calendar year 1983 rather than the financial year, although it did flow over into the 1983-84 financial year-there was a significant increase in Commonwealth outlays solely because of rising unemployment benefits, a cyclical factor with which State governments do not have to contend to nearly the same extent. There was also in calendar year 1984 a significant increase in what were recorded as Commonwealth outlays because of the introduction of Medicare, whereas previously a good deal of Commonwealth expenditure on health had been hidden as a tax expenditure. So there are those complications in the first place.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have enough information to pass a valid opinion, but I will mention one way in which the Victorian Government has made it hard for the Commonwealth. This is a condition which pre-dates the present Victorian Government. Victoria is very much a pacesetter when it comes to wages and conditions for government employees. The general enrichment in both numbers and salaries which prevails in Victoria, and has done for a very long time, makes it difficult for other governments throughout Australia to resist pressures for the same sorts of conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It concerns the vital manufacturing sector of the economy. Has the Government noted new information both on costs faced by Australian manufacturers and on prices paid for products sold by manufacturing industry? If so, can the Minister indicate the Government's response to these price indexes for manufacturing industry purchases and production?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the series to which Senator Maguire refers. The most notable thing it shows is that the cost of all materials used in manufacturing fell by 8.4 per cent in the month of March, which is the largest monthly price fall ever recorded. Of course, the implications of that for manufacturing industry are very favourable. It means that the costs of manufacturing in Australia have been reduced substantially. It is true that the largest part of the fall was due to the falling price of oil, whether imported or purchased in Australia. To be balanced about this, one should concede that manufacturers in other countries generally receive the same sorts of cost advantages, that is, cost reductions, because of the falling oil price, and in some countries probably receive a somewhat greater reduction in cost because of that factor in isolation.

ANSWER.PARA: The all imported materials index fell by 4.2 per cent in the same month. Similarly, about 90 per cent of that was due to lower prices for imported crude petroleum. The monthly figures are significant when one realises that the costs of materials used in manufacturing have fallen by 2.2 per cent over the 12 months from March 1985 to March 1986, notwithstanding the fact that, because of the devaluation of the dollar, the cost in Australian dollar terms for some imported inputs to manufacturing industry would have gone up. Materials, of course, are not the only input to manufacturing, so the effects on the prices of articles produced by manufacturing were somewhat less. The all manufacturing index of prices fell by 0.6 per cent in March, which was the first decrease in that index since November 1970.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which year was that?

—November 1970, almost 16 years ago. It is the first time that that index of articles produced by manufacturing has actually fallen in a month. While the effects of increases in excises on certain petroleum products are excluded from this index, the figures demonstrate the beneficial effects of reductions in the cost of oil on other sectors of the economy.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. In view of the decision by the Greater London Regional Labour Party to ban family snapshots of political candidates because of the offence they create in discriminating against homosexuals and lesbians, can the Minister indicate which sections of the Human Rights Commission Act and the Sex Discrimination Act will be used to provide similar protection in Australia?
—The decisions of a particular ratty branch of the British Labour Party have no relevance to any policies or legislation supported by our Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICAN DEFENCE CAMPAIGN OF AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Special Minister of State seen the article in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph entitled `White terrorism down under'? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: Ultra right wing reactionaries, who champion the extreme elements of South African white rule, are slowly but surely gathering influence in Australia's political underground.

The article links the South African Defence Campaign of Australia-SADCA-with two recent violent attacks on an African restaurant in Glebe, Sydney, and mentions four other incidents of racist violence with which this group may be linked. Can the Minister detail any information he has on the activities of members of SADCA? Is there any evidence of a link between the Sydney based group SADCA and the rise of neo-nazi groups in South Africa? Are any of the members of SADCA newly arrived from South Africa, Australian citizens, or citizens of other countries? What is the Government able to do to control the activities of these neo-nazi groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to give any specific information on SADCA. I will see what the Minister is able to offer in due course about that group. But I do have a brief which I think is relevant on the action being taken to ensure that Australians are protected from all forms of terrorism and politically motivated violence. The situation is this: Although Australia has so far been relatively free from international terrorism, it has in recent years made extensive preparations to counter terrorist threats. For example, a national counter- terrorist capability has been developed through co-operation between the Federal and State governments. This has included the provision of special equipment and training-at a cost of $8.2m to the Commonwealth since 1980-for all police forces. These forces now have elements with a special counter-terrorist capability.

ANSWER.PARA: A national anti-terrorist plan has been prepared to ensure a co-ordinated response to an incident and to provide for effective crisis management. These arrangements are regularly tested in exercise programs. The Australian Defence Force has detailed plans for the provision of aid to the civil power. Australia has a well developed intelligence exchange system with many other countries on the subject of terrorism. The Commonwealth is co-ordinating a program for the protection from terrorism of installations of national economic importance, including off-shore oil rigs and matters of that kind. Finally, Australia has ratified several international conventions on terrorism, including aircraft hijacking, and has expressed support for various other international proposals.

Recently the Government decided to undertake a review of all counter-terrorism capabilities to ensure their continuing efficacy and effectiveness. That review will develop options for an appropriate division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory, as well as options for funding the continuing development of the national counter-terrorism capability. The review is taking into account the relatively unpredictable nature of terrorist activity, the legal responsibilities and international obligations of the Commonwealth in countering terrorism and the responsibilities of the Australian States for the maintenance of order and for breaches of criminal law within their boundaries. The review will embrace aviation security in general, including the adequacy of anti-terrorism measures at airports. I repeat that I am not in a position to respond specifically to the allegation about potential scope for white terrorism in Australia. That allegation would be alarming should it be well founded. I will seek such further information as can be put on the public record about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce embarking on a campaign of softening up the textile, foot- wear and clothing industries with his references to the desirability of removing quota protection? Is he aware that 50,000 jobs are at risk with a tariff-only regime? Do not the sophisticated and diversified economies of the United States of America and the European Economic Community rely on quota protection to prevent destabilisation of their domestic industries? Is it not true that the textile, clothing and footwear industries have invested almost $600m in new buildings and state of the art plants and have done all that is required by the Government, in conformity with the plan? Is not the Government satisfied with overseas penetration, with a 28 per cent increase, 1987 over 1985, based on maximum of quotas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question asks whether I have been embarking on a program of softening up the textile, clothing and footwear industries. The answer to that question is yes. Secondly, I am asked about the desirability of quota regimes--
—With reference to the second part? Softening up with reference to removing quota?

—I am not in a position to comment about that. All I am saying is that the textile, clothing and footwear area is an enormously protected area of the Australian manufacturing economy. Those industries have to understand that the Government's response to the Industries Assistance Commission report, when we get it, will reduce levels of protection for those industries. If that is what the honourable senator means by softening up, the answer is yes, as I said. The mechanism to reduce the level of protection for the textile, clothing and footwear industries remains to be determined and will be announced by the Government in due course.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asks whether the textile, clothing and footwear industries have done everything in accordance with the expressed wishes of the 1982 textile, clothing and footwear plan-whatever they were; I was not in government at the time. Whatever the expressed wishes of that plan were, I think the answer is that one cannot generalise about this matter. Some parts of the industry have complied with the plan; some have not. As Senator Watson knows, massive structural changes have been taking place within those industries in any event. Those structural changes represent, in a sense, a reduction in the number of less efficient companies in the industry. That has been going on for the duration of the plan. With respect to the honourable senator, I do not think anybody would say of an industry such as this that all parts of it had been terrific, that they had all conformed, and therefore we will give them all another great slab of protection into the next decade. If that is the implication of the question, my answer is that that will not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Education advise what initiatives have been or are to be taken to implement the recommendations of the Quality of Education Review Committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of the initiatives have already been implemented insofar as the resource agreements with the States have been completed and the four national priorities identified in the Karmel report of the Quality of Education Review Committee have been incorporated into those resource agreements. In other words, the extra recurrent funding that the Government has made available to the State systems and the non-government systems has been directed to the four areas of national priority, which are basic learning in primary schools; increased participation in years 11 and 12, especially by disadvantaged groups; the encouragement of girls to take subjects right across the curriculum; and the professional development of teachers to assist them to accept these new challenges.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of some of the other recommendations of the Karmel Committee report-for example, the changes it has recommended to some of the special purpose programs of the Commonwealth Schools Commission-the Government has available to it a report from the Schools Commission following consultations held with all relevant parties on that and also is seeking the views of our own Caucus committees on that matter. Towards the end of the year further decisions will be made based on the responses to that report, the responses to the Schools Commission report on the special purpose programs-that is, the Quality and Equality Report-and the follow-up to the resource agreements with the States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and relates to the efforts of the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva to achieve a draft treaty to ban chemical and biological warfare-a concept and a treaty fully supported by the coalition parties. I refer also to the draft treaty banning chemical warfare submitted to the Conference by the Vice-President of the United States of America, Mr Bush-a draft which, in my understanding, is acceptable to both the coalition and the Government. Is it a fact that there is proven evidence that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics over many years has been building and deploying huge stocks of chemical and biological weapons and equipping and training Warsaw Pact troops in their use? Is it also a fact that the United States of America since 1970 had refrained from manufacturing such weapons and had sought earnestly to get agreement to their banning? Does not this Soviet action create a major threat and imbalance in the field of so-called conventional warfare? Will the Government make known to the Australian public the nature and fearful threat of the Soviet stockpile, training and deployment? Will the Government, while increasing its efforts to achieve a draft treaty, communicate to the Soviet Government this country's abhorrence of its action in this field?
—I will take that question on notice and seek an early reply.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Transport seen a letter from the Queensland Main Roads Department threatening to cut pensioners' concessional motor vehicle registrations because of a shortage of funds in the Department's roads program? How much increase has there been in Commonwealth roads funding to Queensland over the past three years? Why is the Queensland Main Roads Department short of funds? Why should Queensland pensioners lose one of their few concessions just because the Queensland Government cannot manage its economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate and, indeed, the Australian public have been discussing the fringe benefits tax quite considerably over the past week or so. Of course, fringe benefits available to pensioners throughout Australia are dependent upon the generosity or otherwise of the particular States. Queensland happens to be the one State that does not extend that generosity in the area of electricity charges. Therefore, pensioners in Queensland are considerably disadvantaged compared with pensioners in other States.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the letter to which Senator Reynolds referred, which indicates a tightening up by the Queensland Government, through the Main Roads Department, in respect of the eligibility of pensioners for motor vehicle registration concessions. That, of course, would put Queensland in a bad comparative position with other States. One finds it difficult to understand how the Queensland Government could possibly justify that particular tightening up of the regulations, because tremendous funding arrangements exist so far as Queensland and the Commonwealth are concerned. For example, by 1988 the Commonwealth intends to spend in Queensland, on the Bruce Highway alone, some $355m. In the current financial year the Commonwealth Government has allocated $70m to that particular project. That means that, since this Government came to office, Federal funding for Queensland's main roads system has increased by 53 per cent. The State's contributions are down 15 per cent, so one can only say that there are some deficiencies in the economic management by the Queensland Government. One can, therefore, appreciate why the Liberal Party in Queensland is as outspoken as it is in its criticism of the Queensland Government and also why the Labor Party in Queensland is on the way back in respect of the elections that will take place this year.

An analysis would show that in Queensland there is a certain degree of cronyism or paternalism about the way in which road funds are allocated within the State's main roads system. I thank the Queensland senator for drawing attention to the letter which has been sent to Queensland pensioners, which certainly indicates that not only do Queenslanders miss out on electricity concessions but also they are going to have an important concession withdrawn from them unless they meet tightened up criteria, which would certainly place them at a disadvantage as far as fringe benefits are concerned in that State.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to you, Mr President. I ask: Have you received a letter from Mr David Barnett of the Bulletin contesting Senator Walsh's claim about his level of earnings in 1975-76 as the previous Prime Minister's Press Secretary and seeking protection from incorrect allegations made under privilege? Will you examine the matter and report to the Senate on the accuracy or otherwise of Senator Walsh's claim? I note, incidentally, that Senator Walsh claimed that Mr Barnett had received an income of about $102,000 and that Mr Barnett claims his income was a little over $41,000. Since it is a public salary, no doubt the facts are very simply verifiable. What remedy is available to any citizen who is subject in this place to allegations which are wrong or inaccurate? If there is no current remedy, will you consider the matter, either alone or in association with the Standing Orders Committee, and report to the Senate on how corrections might be made in appropriate cases?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Shortly prior to Question Time commencing I received a letter from Mr Barnett relating to recent comments made in the Senate by the Minister for Finance with respect to salary and allowances paid to Mr Barnett when he was in the employ of a former Prime Minister. Mr Barnett, in his letter, asserted that the claims made public by Senator Walsh were not accurate and asserted that he had a right to have them corrected in the Parliament. That, as I understand it, is not a matter for the President to comment on. I understand that, according to Mr Barnett, copies of the letter were sent to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and to the Leader of the Opposition.

INTERJECT.PARA: In his letter Mr Barnett referred to the rights of private citizens to be protected from incorrect allegations made under privilege, but with respect to that aspect I again state that I have no comment to make. That suggestion has been made on many occasions before this but no proposal on that aspect has come forward from the Joint Standing Committee on Parliamentary Privilege or from anyone else to alter parliamentary law on the subject. Senator Chaney, of course, is a member of the Standing Orders Committee, and should he like to raise the matter at a meeting of the Standing Orders Committee, he is quite entitled so to do. I also mention that during Question Time, about half an hour ago, Senator Walsh came to me and stated that at the end of Question Time he would seek leave to make a personal explanation on that subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to table the letter that I referred to in my question.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Community Services, concerns the statement by Katharine West, broadcast on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program this morning, in which she said, with reference to unemployment benefit:

QUESTION.PARA: Nobody should be paid from the public or private purse for work not done.
What would be the economic and social effects if such a policy were implemented by government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I heard Katharine West make that statement on AM this morning. I have heard her make that statement on other broadcasts and I have read that statement by her in the endless series of articles she writes for the Australian newspaper, all of which seem the same although the words are slightly different occasionally. I suppose if one took the words just as Ms West said them-that nobody should be paid from the public or private purse for work not done-most of us would agree with them. However, what she is suggesting is that no one should receive any money from the public purse for such things as unemployment benefit, single parent benefit and so on. Therefore, what Ms West is suggesting is that we introduce into this country a system whereby those who are unfortunate enough to be out of work or who are unable to support themselves for other reasons should receive nothing. That would make Australia unique in the Western World. It would put us on a par with some very poor and underdeveloped countries and it would also put us on a par, incidentally, with some of the totalitarian countries of the Right and the Left.
—Like banana republics.

—I have not heard even Senator Walters advocating a policy like Ms West's in this place and one would have to be pretty far to the right to get to the right of Senator Walters. The result of such a policy would simply be that people would starve in the streets, children would suffer from malnutrition and die and there would be people who could not afford medical treatment or many of the basic things that we believe are necessary in this society. I suppose Ms West wants us to return to the economic and social law of the jungle. I do not think that any thinking citizen of this country would want that situation to arise.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, Ms West wanders around this country getting cheap applause for points that she makes to selected audiences which are willing to pay money to hear her speak and I understand that she receives considerable amounts of money to speak at these gatherings. I suppose her long term aim is to do what she suggests should be done in some of her earlier articles-to set up another political party, one that will find a place in it for Ms West. I think Ms West should do what the rest of us have done-put herself and her loony ideas up for judgment by the people at the next election. We will see how she goes. I suggest that she should accept the judgment of the people at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to do that?
—If Senator Sir John Carrick wishes to join Ms West in that loony party, let him do so.
—He is not that bad.
—I did not think he was that bad either; but if he wants to interject in that way, let him do so.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is he aware of the correspondence to the Prime Minister from the President of the Tax Institute of Australia in which he said that the Institute was concerned that unnecessary hardship might be occasioned by the provisions in the tax Bills which were passed recently by the Parliament? Will the Minister undertake that the Government will give serious consideration to the matters contained in that letter, report to the Senate and detail the comments of the Prime Minister on the matters raised? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today Senator Sanders asked me a question about bombing on the Beecroft Peninsula. I am now able to respond to him. Mirage aircraft of 77 Squadron did conduct training on the range on both days in question. On each day 24 MK82 HE/HES bombs were dropped. Each bomb has an explosive charge of about 20 lbs. Initial investigations reveal that, as far as can be observed from the shore, there does not appear to be any obvious damage to the island.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the other questions, the Department of Defence needs to retain the use of the Beecroft range to enable vital defence capabilities to be maintained. The use of the Beecroft range by Defence has been on-going since 1941. Steps taken to ensure personnel safety include the publication of regular warning notices in the local Press and the issue of warning notices to airmen and local mariners. Beecroft is a designated weapons practice range managed by the Royal Australian Navy for the Department of Defence. Mobile range clearance is given by range staff prior to the commencement of the bombardment serials. The eastern half of Beecroft Peninsula is closed to public access during bombardment serials and red warning flags are hoisted at appropriate access positions adjacent to the bombardment impact area. There is manning of the naval ranger's station by the naval ranger or a substitute during bombardments. He is available to provide advice to members of the public and to control vehicular access onto the range. There is constant and close monitoring of the impact area by the ranger safety officer and positive control of each bombardment.

Preservation of significant landmarks is addressed by the Beecroft draft land management plan which has been recently reviewed and is being given detailed consideration at this moment. A naval ranger has been seconded from the Department of Territories to implement and manage the Beecroft land management plan. The provision of the naval ranger on weekends ensures that the Beecroft Peninsula remains open to the public for enjoyment when Defence is not using it.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CITIZENSHIP AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted earlier today I had nearly concluded the remarks that I wanted to make about the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill. I was commenting on the Opposition's attitude to the Government's amendments to the legislation, in particular, the amendment to the Australian Citizenship Act which would prevent people who had a child in Australia, while here as visitors or illegal immigrants, from having that child gain Australian citizenship automatically. The Opposition was proposing that, as some sort of compensation to those people, such a person who was born in Australia who was not an Australian citizen should automatically be entitled to an entry permit if he or she wanted to come back at any stage between the ages of 18 and 40. I suggested that the Oppositions's amendment is nonsensical. It is obviously confused about the whole situation. Opposition senators speak about the infringement of traditional rights, but that is not the attitude they have taken to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. They have certainly not stated where this supposedly traditional right is enshrined. One would have thought that if they felt so strongly about this right they would not be agreeing to the principle of the main amendment at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out that there is sufficient compensation built into the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, which provides that a child born to even one parent who is an Australian citizen or permanent resident will automatically acquire Australian citizenship by birth; or if the child would otherwise be stateless, it would acquire Australian citizenship; or if the child's parents are visitors or illegally in Australia but that child has been here for 10 years, it would acquire Australian citizenship automatically. So if it has grown up for that period in Australia it will be treated as an Australian.

The amendment the Opposition proposes to the Migration Amendment Bill cannot be accepted by the Government because it negates the whole purpose of the amendment to the Citizenship Act, which is to ensure that attempted queue jumping in the immigration system is deterred. Australia is an immigrant country and has to deal with over one million applicants every year. Our program entails entry of about 100,000 applicants each year-that is, only one in 10 people who seek to come to Australia are allowed entry-so we have to ensure that attempted queue jumping, whether contrived from the start or accidental, is deterred.

There is nothing in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights or in the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child which requires that children born in Australia of non-citizens should become citizens merely because they were born here. The Government is trying to ensure that the immigration program is not distorted in this way. I re-emphasise that the amendment to the Act has the support of the Human Rights Commission, which had to deal with some of these difficult cases in the past. It will make the system simpler and easier all round. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill because it really does threaten to devalue Australian citizenship by altering the oath and affirmation of allegiance without proper consultation and perhaps without proper forethought. Much of this Bill deals with objectives that are sensible and which the Liberal Party of Australia supports. I do not wish to take up the Senate's time to debate those matters in detail, but I think we should look at some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4 stops a loophole for illegal immigration by removing automatic citizenship for all children born in Australia, ensuring that only those born to a parent who is a permanent resident or a citizen will become citizens. It is also appropriate that clause 7 of this Bill redresses loss of citizenship by those Australians who particularly through residing in Israel have inadvertently lost their citizenship. As many as 2,000 Australians have had Israeli citizenship conferred upon them under the Israeli law of return without realising that since the Australian Citizenship Act was amended in 1984 it has deprived them of Australian citizenship. We support any amendments to assist Australians to regain a citizenship they never intended to renounce and would, in fact, argue that this process should simply require a statement of intention to return to Australia without insisting, as the Government does, that they should return within three years.

These measures display a proper regard for the importance of Australian citizenship, that should no longer be acquired by simple accident of the location of a birth. Yet in the same Bill clause 11 deletes from the oath and the affirmation of allegiance both the need for the applicant to say his name at the beginning of the pledge, and the opening reference to `renouncing all other allegiance'. As a nation, then, our Government does not think it worth while to ask for an individualised and personal commitment to Australia, nor is it thought necessary for Australia to have the undivided allegiance and loyalty of its new citizens.

We are told that the requirement for each applicant to state his name causes confusion. What a pathetic reason in anyone's words for watering down a pledge. Our common sense would tell us that if a citizenship ceremony is conducted with due care and dignity, confusion over such a basic matter would simply not occur. It is just not good enough for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) to claim, as he did on 13 March, that applicants for citizenship are sufficiently identified by being ticked off a list at the beginning of the ceremony and receiving a form. Citizenship acquisition is a solemn and deep event for any man or woman. Rather than try to depersonalise the ceremony, the Government should be looking at ways of enhancing its significance. I fully support the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in his proposal that an attractive, personalised certificate should replace the computerised documents currently used. So, too, stating one's own name before taking an oath or affirmation gives an added and special force to that oath, entirely appropriate when a person acquires Australian citizenship.

In deleting the renunciation of all other allegiances, the Hawke Australian Labor Party Government claims that this has been taken to imply a forced denial of an applicant's culture and of all original ties. While we would all agree that no such sweeping demand should be made of our new citizens, basic common sense once again dictates that the proper course is for renunciation to be clarified rather than abolished. There is all the difference in the world between a person's private, cultural traditions and their identification with the national aspirations of Australia. Citizens of Australia must have this country, and no other, as the sole focus for their political allegiance, whether or not their original country is an ally and friend of our nation. When consultation on a national basis was held in 1982 over this question, there was no clear recommendation that the renunciation clause be deleted. Instead, alternative forms of the oath of allegiance were proposed. What objection can there be to asking applicants to `renounce all other national legal obligations' or to `renounce and abandon all allegiances (if any) to any foreign state'. One does not need to be an expert legal draftsman to come up with a form of words that makes it clear that political and not cultural or family loyalties are being renounced.

To make no mention of renunciation of other political allegiances, however, is to admit that Australia is not worth the undivided loyalty of old or new citizens, and it devalues the citizenship of us all. On such a simple but basic matter, surely a Government that preached consensus might have seen fit either to consult the people of Australia generally, or even the Opposition. It is true that the United Kingdom has a very simple oath of allegiance without any mention of renunciation. It is equally true, however, that Britain receives comparatively few new citizens, as the great majority of those settling there have been citizens of Commonwealth countries who could assume citizenship rights. A far more relevant example to us in Australia is the United States, with its tradition of extensive immigration, and of cultural diversity. People wishing to become American citizens are left in no doubt as to where their political loyalties must now belong. The United States oath of allegiance begins:
I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereignty of whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen.

An applicant for United States citizenship must also promise to defend his new country either as a member of the armed forces or under civilian direction, should the need arise. Moreover, the oath specifies that it is taken freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion. Quite frankly, that is what we would call a binding, iron-clad commitment. While I am not suggesting that we should adopt a similar oath of allegiance, we should note well that the United States regards its citizenship as a solemn privilege that commands undivided loyalty. There is no reason or excuse for us to take a different attitude towards Australian citizenship. We should be aware that in 1983 the Australian values study found that 86 per cent of our citizens and 96 per cent of those people originating from Britain and southern Europe were proud to be Australian. That same pride should be affirmed by the Parliament of Australia by its insisting that the oath and affirmation of allegiance are not diluted in any way by this Bill.

We should all appreciate the type of open patriotism that characterises the United States today. It is not jingoism but a simple pride in and love of America that its citizens and government are not ashamed to display. It is pervasive and bipartisan. Ronald Reagan may capture its mood but it goes a long way beyond his political supporters. Australians are ready to respond as patriots in their own way if only the Hawke Government seeks to foster simple and unaffected patriotism instead of engaging in expansive and spurious quests to create and discover some national identity allied to an artificial and heavy-handed multiculturalism.

While most members and supporters of the Australian Labor Party are proud Australians, like the rest of us, it is disturbing to see that through this and other actions they are pandering to the minorities for whom, quite frankly, `patriotism' is a dirty word. One such person, associated with the Australian studies Bicentennial project, is Craig McGregor, who wrote last October that Australia has no identity but is merely a collection of minorities. Furthermore, in McGregor's view, being a patriot involves racism, greed, insularity, sexism and a sort of pointless pride. Most Australians would repudiate this nihilistic garbage and so should their elected government. Instead, we get a devalued oath of allegiance and such dubious gestures as a grant of $3,000 to Ausflag so that it can undermine the most basic symbol of our nationhood.

Unless genuine patriotism and true Australian nationalism are promoted, we will indeed face the threat of becoming nothing more than a collection of self-regarding minorities. Identification with a traditional culture is a matter of individual preference that should not require extensive policies of government intervention. Australia has always had its own forms of multiculturalism. The cultural differences between those of English and Irish origin in earlier generations were just as sharp as, and more bitter than, contemporary differences stemming from post-war migration. What I object to is when a government is so concerned to sponsor multiculturalism as a policy rather than a natural development that it devalues Australian citizenship-as the Government does in this Bill-lest any prospective citizens and prospective voters object to proclaiming their undivided allegiance to a common Australian nation.

We are moving from the welcome acceptance of diversity to its promotion at the public expense. In so doing, this Government runs the risk of weakening our sense of nationhood. Again, we should remember that few countries could be as racially or culturally diverse as the United States. Nonetheless, it is bound together by a simple and common patriotism. It should have disturbed all thoughtful Australians last year when a delegation of left wing members of the Greek community threatened to put political pressure on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to ensure that United States communications facilities in this country were not used to aid surveillance over Greece.

This is a prime example of a minority group, unrepresentative of Australians of Greek origin, owing a continued allegiance to a foreign government that could inspire political action within Australia. The culture and family loyalties of those who choose to become Australians are their own, just as much as their religion. However, Australia can and should demand that its citizens give their full and unstinting allegiance to Australia to the exclusion of other political loyalties. Governments have a duty to encourage citizenship but at the same time must uphold the intrinsic value of Australian citizenship as a partnership in our nation. The Hawke Government can only weaken Australian patriotism by both depersonalising the oath of allegiance and failing to insist on a renunciation of allegiances to other states.
Clause 11 of this Bill should not be passed. In 1941 John Curtin, in a broadcast to the people of the Unites States of America, said:

I give you the pledge of my country. There will always be an Australian Government and there will always be an Australian people. We are too strong in our hearts, our spirit is too high, the justice of our cause throbs too deeply in our being, for that high purpose to be overcome.
One might ask: What price this kind of basic patriotism in the Australia of 1986?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition cannot agree with the Australian Democrats and the Government that the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1986 are innocuous. They are like the curate's egg; they are good in parts. We see the bad parts as part of a continued and progressive denigration of the status of Australian citizenship. If the Government continues in the way it is going it will virtually reduce Australia to the status of a bus stop for migrants as they pass through without any feeling of love of country and patriotism, just referred to by Senator Knowles.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was picking up time before being elected to this place in 1984 the Government watered down the citizenship legislation. To put in perspective just what is happening to citizenship in Australia I would like to mention three or four of the actions the Government took then to water down the status of citizenship. The first thing it did was to reduce the qualifying period from three years to two years. It then relaxed the continuous residence requirement from 12 months immediately preceding the application to 12 months residence in the previous two years. It amended the requirement that an applicant for citizenship demonstrate an adequate knowledge of the English language. The requirement was then set that an applicant demonstrate a basic knowledge of English and applicants over 50 years of age were exempt altogether. The Government, consistent with its reform of the Migration Act, repealed the definition of the `British subject' status. The Government is now saying that migrants do not have to give their name when they attend their citizenship ceremony and they do not have to make a renunciation of previous allegiance.

The Bills have four main objectives, three of which are reasonably innocuous. The first one ends the automatic granting of citizenship to children born in Australia to visitors, to temporary entrants and to illegal immigrants and is quite satisfactory. The Migration Amendment Bill 1986 also provides for the legal status of such children. The second objective is to allow lines of appeal for those who have lost their citizenship under special circumstances or who have not been granted citizenship due to error. Removing the so-called sexist language from the principal Act is relatively innocuous. The measure which significantly changes the oath or affirmation of allegiance which is taken by citizenship applicants is the one that we object to and hope will be amended.

The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986 amends the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 to do two main things: First, to remove the requirement of citizenship applicants to state their name when swearing their allegiance to Australia; and secondly, to remove the need for renunciation of any former allegiance from our oath or affirmation. The change apparently follows the recommendation of the now infamous Human Rights Commission, which seems to be acquiring almost Australian Council of Trade Union-like powers over the Government in its policy making.

I am on the Opposition immigration and ethnic affairs committee. I agree that the Opposition was not consulted on the introduction of this Bill. As I have listened to the debate this afternoon I have come to realise that there has been even less consultation with many groups in the community. It is no wonder the introduction of this Bill has caused such consternation. It is common for the Government not to consult on things; for example, the establishment of the Australian Sports Commission and the abolition of our national anthem. In lots of areas the Government rides rough-shod over the community; it has done so even with the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. It was mentioned earlier that the previous Government had commissioned a report called the `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship' report. The general thrust of that report was specifically against changes of the kind which are being brought about by this legislation.

The reasons given for introducing this legislation include an absurd claim that renouncing allegiance is offensive to prospective citizens, that it is inconsistent with multicultural objectives-whatever that is. It might well be inconsistent with the more sinister objectives of multiculturalism, but anyone who, as a prospective Australian citizen, finds renouncing his allegiance to a foreign power offensive does not really deserve to be an Australian citizen. The claim that renouncing former allegiance must be interpreted as a renunciation of cultural heritage and traditions is straightout rubbish and ranks with the wisdom seen in the former Greater London Council which banned black garbage bags because it thought that they were racist. The logical corollary to the claim that recognising former ties is offensive is that Australian citizenship itself is offensive, so why have Australian citizenship at all? I do not suppose the Government would think that there is any logic in that statement, but if citizenship of another country is found to be offensive, why is not Australian citizenship itself offensive? The Human Rights Commission, which inspired this change to the oath, is clearly part of Australia's loony Left, as was mentioned in today's Question Time-an equivalent to the Greater London Council mentioned.

While I was in Melbourne I visited the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. It has offices in each State but its headquarters are in Melbourne. It meets and has conferences. It is tackling an almost mission impossible with a will and a zeal. It is trying a new concept of multiculturalism in Australia which has not been tried anywhere else in the world. It has many models to work from. Europe has had about 2,000 years of multiculturalism and still it is not settled. The United States of America has a policy of enforced integration. South Africa has enforced segregation. Canada has multinational and multi- racial problems, with Eskimos, Indians, French people, Europeans and black people. The United Kingdom has a system of voluntary segregation. It has Welsh, Scottish, English, Irish and Manx people. It has another imported problem, with people from the Commonwealth living in no-go ghetto areas. I have been to Jamaica and the motto of the country is `out of many, one people'.

The Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs is trying to tie all these sorts of matters together to create a new society. But it would be wrong to import a problem that has not been solved around the world and think that we can do it. As yet it is only a minor problem. We have a few indigestible minorities, as they have been called, at the moment. I press that we should not follow policies which will aggravate this minor problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate and their general support for the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill. I do not, of course, thank Opposition senators who, as they do so frequently because of their lack of ideas, grasp a couple of small matters and try to make big issues of them. I disagree with Senator Knowles's jingoistic concept of what Australia is and Australian citizenship should be. I remind Senator Knowles, who quoted John Curtin-a man who was perhaps the greatest Australian Prime Minister-whom incidentally one of her colleagues in a debate only two days ago called a failed Prime Minister-in talking about Australians, that he was talking about British subjects because in those days in 1941 there was no Australian citizenship. When Australian citizenship was introduced in 1948 the Party of which she is such a proud member and for which she waves the flag so much opposed it. That Party wanted us still to be British subjects and not Australian citizens. Australian citizenship is a relatively recent concept and it is not strengthened by jingoistic, pseudo-patriotic nonsense of the type we have heard from Senator Knowles this afternoon.
—It is all too difficult for people to say their names, is it?

—It is not too difficult at all. I will come to that quite definitely in a minute. I would like to quote someone whom I think is a very patriotic Australian, who has been a very distinguished Australian politician and who was a distinguished representative of his Party in ethnic affairs. He said that renouncing all other allegiances was often regarded as meaning abandoning one's own cultural heritage when in fact this was not the case. He said that this was a considerable problem to a lot of people and if it was unnecessary to ask people to do this, they should not be asked to do so. The man who said this is still in the Parliament. His name is Mr Macphee. I understand that in Western Australia he is considered to be a bit of a red. But when he represented the Opposition Parties in ethnic affairs there were not the stupid divisions that we have had in recent times, divisions which have arisen out of the concepts of people such as Senator Knowles who believe that the only way to prove that one is a loyal Australian citizen is to mouth empty, jingoistic words of the type she mouthed this afternoon and to suggest, as she did this afternoon, that some group of people who may say that it might be a good idea to look at our flag as we might want to change it in 1988 have no right to do that and should not do that.
—Do you want to do that?

—No, it is way down on my agenda. I am suggesting that one thing about being Australian is to have the right to suggest that such change can be made without being abused by people such as Senator Knowles, to put one's case in a reasonable way without its being suggested by Senator Knowles that in fact one is a traitor to one's country.
—Was the point not that you have given money for that project?

—No, Senator Knowles made the point that one had no right to do so. That is the point she continues to make. As I suggested, Senator Knowles and her predecessors in fact opposed the introduction of Australian citizenship. They did not want it. They wanted us to remain British subjects. They wanted us to continue our obeisance to that nation. They wanted nothing to do with Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Knowles objects to the removal of the words of renunciation from the oath. If anyone asked me my personal view, independent of government or anything else, I would say that it would not worry me either way. I do not think it should worry anyone either way. I am sure that the fact that the new citizens of Canada do not have to renounce their previous allegiances does not make them less loyal or worse citizens.

I do not think it makes the new citizens of New Zealand any worse because they do not have to renounce previous allegiances. It does not make the new citizens of Great Britain any worse because they do not have to; nor does it make the new citizens of the United States of America any better because they have to. This is a nonsensical argument. I can stand up here and read out a list of countries that have this requirement; I can also read out a list of countries that do not.

The simple fact of the matter is that I think there are two reasons why it is perhaps unnecessary. The first reason was put forward by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia and contained in the report, to which Senator Knowles referred, that was compiled under the previous Government in 1982-that is, that renouncing all other allegiances discourages some immigrants from taking out Australian citizenship, creates confusion and suggests that they might be renouncing their cultural heritage and other ties. These immigrants want to become loyal Australian citizens, fully contributing their skills and cultures to Australia's developing nationhood. They can do so in the multicultural society that Senator Sheil does not like. In fact, the Institute of Multicultural Studies was set up by the previous Government. Senator Sheil does not like it, but he did not say much about it when the coalition parties were in government.

The other reason that the words are not required is in fact that the words themselves have no legal effect at all. As Senator Knowles quite rightly said, they are included in the legislation as a symbolic act of adopting Australian citizenship. But they do not strengthen that act of adopting Australian citizenship. Some people consider that they are an impediment. In fact, they have no legal effect at all in those countries that require people to remain citizens even though they become citizens of other countries. They have no legal effect in countries such as Greece, Italy and Yugoslavia that have dual citizenship arrangements and recognise their citizens as still retaining their original citizenship. The present system creates difficulties for large groups of our new settlers. We do not believe that the removal of this requirement makes people any less worthy citizens or less worthy contributors. That is why the change is in fact being introduced.

Another matter is whether people should state their names when they take the oath or affirmation of allegiance. Since I have been a member of parliament I have noticed when attending citizenship ceremonies-and Senator Knowles also pointed this out-that our new citizens are taking a very large step about which they have thought seriously. Sometimes the preparation involved in taking this step obviously creates considerable emotional turmoil, considerable personal thought and considerable difficulties. I think that the ceremony should be dignified. It should be meaningful to the people involved and meaningful to everyone who attends.

What happens at the moment is that people are called by name and they answer with their name. When they get their certificates they sign for them. Again they are identified by their name. But, when they stand up to take the oath of allegiance en masse, one thing that always stands out is the great confusion at the time when they have to say their names. There is a whole series of names of different lengths and in different languages. I cannot believe that anyone who has watched one of those ceremonies could believe that the ceremony is enhanced by that strange gaggle of sounds that comes out at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could be saying anything.
—As Senator McIntosh has said, they could be saying Ned Kelly, Joseph Stalin, Christopher Puplick or any name they like and no one would have a clue or would know what was going on.
—I was quite happy to do so when I was naturalised.

—I am sure the honourable senator was happy to do so. Anyone with a distinctive name like his would want to do so. But it does not add much to the ceremony. It does not add to the dignity of the occasion. It does not add anything like that. In fact it does not make one bit of difference to the quality of the person's commitment or future citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: I will agree with Senator Knowles, if she will not faint, that we ought to do something about the citizenship certificate. It is not the sort of quality that we should give to people. Sure, we should do something about that. I understand that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has that in mind. But to suggest that anything is gained from the strange ritual that happens now at citizenship ceremonies is stretching things a bit.

I know that a party that is bereft of ideas with which to stimulate the electorate of this country has to go to pretty desperate lengths to sound good and to sound as though it is being patriotic. We have to put up with speeches like the one from Senator Knowles.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're about as colourful as a black and white movie. Get on with it.

—I do not try to be colourful. She is the one who tries to be colourful, but the trouble is that she ends up being jingoistic and chauvinistic. The changes that have been introduced have not been introduced in a hurry. This legislation has been on the Notice Paper for months. I see that Senator Messner wants to get out of the place; he keeps pointing to his watch whereas Senator Knowles tells me that we have not given this legislation sufficient seriousness.
—You won't get your Bills then.

—I do not mind; the honourable senator need not worry about it. I thank honourable senators for their assistance with this legislation. I wish that the Opposition would take the legislation more seriously and not try to score cheap political points from it. The legislation was introduced for a serious purpose. It has been introduced after consultation with the community since 1981. It has the support of the migrant community generally. I suggest that it has the support of all thinking Australians, and I urge the Senate to give it a rapid passage despite Senator Messner's disturbed state of mind.
