SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, sub-clause 7 (1), proposed sub-sub-paragraph 23aa (1) (b) (iv) (b), lines 27 to 29, leave out ``and before the expiration of the period of 3 years commencing on the day on which the statement is made''.
(2) Page 4, sub-clause 7 (1), proposed paragraph 23aa (1) (e), lines 39 and 40, leave out ``hardship or detriment of an economic nature'', insert ``significant hardship or detriment''.

The point of the first amendment is to correct the situation whereby the Government has imposed a limit upon the time in which people need to have resided in Australia to reinstate their citizenship after a period of absence from Australia. The Opposition's amendment seeks to widen that so that the residence period becomes unlimited. This will assist those individuals who, for various reasons which were discussed during the second reading debate, find themselves caught outside Australia. The Opposition is not making any cheap shots, as the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) sought to do in his last few remarks. In fact, on a question of principle, which we will deal with a little later, we are very firmly in favour of maintaining the present wording of the oath and the affirmation. We believe that people ought to have the maximum opportunity to seek reinstatement of their citizenship in cases of hardship of various kinds because of their having to accept foreign citizenship in certain circumstances.

In the Government's amending legislation there appears to be an inconsistency. Proposed new section 23aa (b) (i) contains a reference to the Minister having received a statement from the applicant in which the applicant sets out the fact that he or she has suffered significant hardship or detriment, yet under paragraph (d), when the Minister is required to exercise his discretion, he needs to satisfy himself that the person would have suffered hardship or detriment of an economic nature. Apparently the applicant in the first place can offer reasons for his hardship on a wide basis, but when the Minister is required to make a decision about that and exercise his discretion, he is limited to making decisions only on economic hardship grounds. I do not understand the reason for the difference, but assuming that the Government did intend that, it seems unreasonable that it should be limited to reasons of economic hardship and detriment only. For that reason, I believe our amendment is quite reasonable. It will make the two points quite consistent. If the applicant does seek to have his position considered by the Minister, he will put down those reasons and they will be considered by the Minister on the same basis and on the same grounds when he comes to exercise his discretion. Perhaps the Minister can offer some reason why that wording is used in the Bill, but we are at a loss to understand it. That is why I have moved the amendments which have been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that the points Senator Messner has made are serious, but we do not accept the amendments, for reasons I will make clear. The period of three years was chosen as a reasonable period and it coincides with the three-year period within which a permanent resident who leaves Australia with a return endorsement on his or her passport must return to Australia. We think it is a reasonable period. We do not believe that the Opposition's proposal for people to make a commitment to return in an unlimited time or in 20 years, or whatever, is any commitment at all. Why ask people to make a commitment if they do not ever have to fulfil that commitment? There are two tests which the Bill requires. Where the applicant is in Australia, the applicant must say that that residence will continue. If the applicant is outside Australia, under the amendment the Opposition has moved he or she need not return at all. We do not see much point in including that in the Bill; we see a very good point in retaining the existing wording of the legislation. We do not see much point at all in the sort of amendment that Senator Messner is putting forward. Senator Knowles and others talked earlier about commitment, yet the amendment the Opposition has put up makes no commitment at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not understand the reason for the second amendment and I do not understand the inconsistency that Senator Messner refers to, any more than the draftsman, Mr Hurford or anyone else understood the inconsistency raised in another place in similar circumstances. The provision requires applicants who have lost citizenship as a result of acquiring another for economic reasons to especially satisfy the Minister, when seeking to resume citizenship, that they were compelled to take the foreign citizenship. If the hardship they would have faced by not taking that foreign citizenship was non-economic, they need not demonstrate such compulsion. I do not see any inconsistency in that; I see good sense in it. I do not see what the Opposition's hangup is about this clause. For reasons I have stated, and for reasons that were amply stated in debate in the other place, we do not accept that it is necessary to amend the legislation in this way.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 11 of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, which implements the change to the oath. We debated this matter at quite some length during the second reading debate, but I restate the Opposition's position in regard to this clause. Two major changes to the oath are proposed to this legislation by the Hawke Government. Firstly, a person adopting the new form of the oath will not be required to state his or her name. We have taken objection to that point because we believe that the act of accepting Australian citizenship is a most personal and individual act. Consequently, the elimination of the simple thing of a person not being able to state his or her name appears to us to be absolutely incongruous and certainly is not consistent with the general principles of what is intended when people accept citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point relates more significantly to the question of renunciation of all other allegiance. The Government's amendment deletes reference to that renunciation. The point the Opposition makes quite clearly here is that it is surely fundamental to the acceptance of Australian citizenship that a person accepting that citizenship should renounce all intention, mental, physical or whatever, of retaining any former allegiance, and that it is a positive part of taking the oath in favour of Australian allegiance that one should, at the same time, renounce all connection with any other foreign power. It is not as though this is some new thing. It is certainly part of other countries' oaths or affirmations of allegiance. We heard from Senator Knowles, for instance, of the situation in the United States of America, where the requirement is even more stringent than the requirement in our oath which the Government is proposing to amend. I think the point needs to be strongly reiterated by the Opposition that we believe that that renunciation act is a positive statement of acceptance of Australian citizenship and, as such, means that people are identifying thereafter clearly with Australian citizenship. The Government, of course, argued the opposite point-that people confused that acceptance of Australian citizenship and the renunciation of their former citizenship as being a renunciation of their cultural heritage, background and so on. That is simply not true because Australia is a multicultural society where people do maintain their private and personal cultural habits, no matter what background they come from-whether they were born in this country or born outside this country. The two issues are entirely separate.

We see no reason why the Government should delete this reference to the renunciation of other allegiances because of that. I understand, too, that the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Alan Cadman, has had responses from no less than 354 local government authorities all over Australia in support of the coalition's position on this particular matter. On the other hand, only four people have written to him supporting the Government's position on these amendments. Quite clearly then from right on the ground where these citizenship ceremonies are held there is vast support from local government authorities for the position of the coalition on this matter. They support the inclusion of that positive statement that there should be renunciation of all former allegiance as part of acceptance of Australian citizenship.

I believe that the arguments put forward by my colleagues, particularly by Senator Knowles and Senator Sheil, quite clearly demonstrate that we in this country should be standing up and valuing our citizenship, perhaps to an extent greater than we have in the past. For the Government to move in precisely the opposite direction obviously will lead to the devaluation of Australian citizenship. I move:
Page 6, clause 11, lines 22 to 26, leave out the clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot support the Liberal Party of Australia on this matter for the reasons I stated in the second reading debate. Presently the Government proposes to leave in an oath that candidates for naturalisation will be loyal to Her Majesty and that they will swear that they will observe the laws of Australia and will fulfil their duties as Australian citizens. What more do honourable senators want? If we demand that they now renounce all former allegiances, I know, having been to many of these ceremonies, that these people will get confused. They believe that using those words means that they cannot wear their former national costumes or engage in their folk dances or whatever. For that and other reasons, we support the Government in this matter. We do not support the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendment moved by Senator Messner for the reasons outlined by Senator Chipp. I resent the implication that what we are doing is degrading Australian citizenship or that we, or anyone else, are less effective and loyal Australian citizens as a result of this. We could go on all day on this matter, but I simply point out that the citizens of Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom are not required to give their names when they become new citizens and they are no lesser citizens for it. I do not think that citizens of the United States or other countries who have to give their names are any the better for it, nor are their countries any the better for it. I hope we do not get to a situation in which this provision goes in and out of the legislation with every change of government. Judging from history, I do not think that will happen. Once the change is made, it will stay there and I think that is for the good of us all.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Defence aware of the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, tabled on 24 November 1981, entitled Threats to Australia's Security: Their Nature and Probability, which concluded, inter alia, that:

``it would be prudent for Australian defence planners to assume that the joint facilities at North West Cape, Pine Gap and Nurrungar are on the Soviet target list and might be attacked in the course of a nuclear conflict between the two superpowers. In other words, there is a finite risk that one or all of the facilities would be attacked during a Soviet-United States war that involved their nuclear strategic forces'' (p. 19).

(2) Is the Minister aware of studies which suggest that under some circumstances (e.g. a one megaton ground burst at a time of south easterly winds) a nuclear attack on Pine Gap could kill most of the people in the Alice Springs area in the absence of civil defence preparations; if so, what civil defence measures (such as evacuation plans or fallout shelter plans):
(a) have been prepared; or
(b) are in the process of being prepared in order to protect the people of Alice Springs and surrounding areas from this eventuality.

(3) Is the Minister aware of studies which suggest that under some circumstances (e.g. a one megaton ground burst at a time of north-westerly winds) a nuclear attack on Nurrungar could kill perhaps more than 10,000 people in the Port Augusta, Whyalla and Port Pirie area and cause perhaps another 100,000 people to suffer various forms of radiation illness and damage; if so, what civil defence measures (such as evacuation plans or fallout shelter plans):
(a) have been prepared; or
(b) are in the process of being prepared in order to protect the people of Port Augusta, Whyalla, Port Pirie and surrounding areas from this eventuality.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, our intelligence and defence authorities have for many years assessed the risk of nuclear war as remote and improbable, provided that effective deterrence is maintained. As the Prime Minister said in his statement on the joint facilities on 6 June 1984, Australia's hosting of the joint defence facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap contributes to the effectiveness of deterrence.

(2) and (3) I am not aware of any detailed studies which support the conclusions mentioned in these questions, although I am aware that certain broad judgments have been made to that effect. Those judgments, and the scenarios mentioned in the honourable member's question, do not provide an adequate basis for civil defence planning against the risk of nuclear attack on the joint defence facilities. For example, I would note that because the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap lies some 18km to the south-west of Alice Springs, the fallout from a one megaton ground burst at Pine Gap at a time of south easterly winds would not be carried towards that community; the consequences postulated would not therefore appear credible. Furthermore, the suggested scale of fatalities in the Port Augusta, Whyalla and Port Pirie area could only occur if people chose to stay in contaminated areas there for several days; this is not a realistic assumption to make.

The Department of Defence is reviewing the need for civil defence measures to protect the communities situated near the joint defence facilities. This work is intended to provide a basis for discussions which the Natural Disasters Organisation might hold with State and Territory emergency services organizations, aimed at establishing the need for further precautionary civil defence planning work to be carried out in this area.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Darling Harbour Bicentennial Project: Employment of Builders Labourers Federation Members

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 April 1986 (Hansard, page 1650), Senator Puplick asked me a question, without notice, regarding the employment of Builders Labourers Federation members at the Darling Harbour bicentennial project. Senator Puplick asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Government agreed to allocate $30m, including $8m in supplementary estimates currently before the Senate, to the Government of New South Wales for work on a bicentennial project at Sydney's Darling Harbour? Is the Government aware that the New South Wales Labor Government has entered into what is claimed by the union to be a water tight arrangement with the Builders Labourers Federation which guarantees the continued employment of BLF members at Darling Harbour, regardless of the deregistration of the union and its exclusion from the conciliation and arbitration system? Does the Government believe that it is proper to pay taxpayer's money to the New South Wales Government which can only spend it on a project which exclusively employs members of the BLF as part of some covert sweetheart deal?
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised that the Commonwealth under the Bicentennial Program has allocated $30m for the building of a National Maritime Museum at the Darling Harbour Project. This amount will be paid through the National Maritime College to the Darling Harbour Authority. A further $8m is being sought to cover fit out, salaries and acquisitions for the Museum.

Regarding an alleged agreement with the Builders Labourers Federation at the site, I took this matter up with the New South Wales Minister for Public Works, Ports and Roads, the Honourable L. J. Brereton MLA, who has advised me as follows:
`The commitment of the New South Wales Government to the code of conduct adopted in relation to the Builders Labourers Federation remains unchanged.

The article you quote suggested that some special arrangements existed which would circumvent the intention of that code. No such arrangement has been reached with the Builders Labourers Federation, or with any other Union working on the Darling Harbour redevelopment.

The terms and conditions of the Site Agreement reached with the Unions apply to all Unions without variation. One of the fundamental principles of the Darling Harbour Site Agreement is that this is a union site and only paid up union members are allowed to work on the site.
The Darling Harbour redevelopment is in exactly the same position, viz. the Builders Labourers Federation, as any other major construction site in New South Wales, Victoria and the A.C.T.
I have already refuted the suggestions of a ``Special Arrangement'' with the Builders Labourers Federation in the State Parliament.'

Following the coming into force of Regulations made under the Builders Labourers Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Act on 15 April 1986 all the former members of the BLF working on this project were enrolled by the other unions concerned.
